This was not the first time I had come to the emergency department; I had multiple visits over the past few months for self-inflicted wounds. I expressed to my boyfriend that I believe he is the worst person in the world, and our relationship has been tumultuous, having broken up 20 times in the past six months.

I made the decision to cut myself not out of a desire to end my life, but rather because I feel alone and empty. I was hoping my boyfriend would take care of me during these difficult moments. He has mentioned that I tend to have outbursts of physical aggression and experience significant mood swings. These mood swings can shift from feelings of exuberance and self-confidence to self-doubt and melancholy, often occurring within a few hours.

When I was examined, I appeared well-dressed and calm. My speech was normal, and my thought processes and content were clear. Despite my struggles, I want to convey that I am seeking understanding and support for what I am experiencing.
options: A. Bipolar I disorder B. Narcissistic personality disorder C. Histrionic personality disorder D. Cyclothymic disorder E. Antisocial personality disorder F. Dependent personality disorder G. Bipolar II disorder H. Borderline personality disorder
default:
Thanks for sharing this — you described a lot of important details. Based on what you’ve said, the pattern fits borderline personality disorder (BPD) as the most likely explanation: repeated self‑injury without clear intent to die, unstable and intense relationships with idealization/devaluation, marked mood reactivity with shifts over hours, chronic feelings of emptiness, and episodes of anger/impulsivity. These are classic features of BPD, though a formal diagnosis requires a clinical interview.

Why I say this (brief):
- Recurrent self‑harm used to regulate emotion or get care rather than to die.  
- Pattern of stormy relationships (broken up many times; “worst person in the world” then wanting care).  
- Rapid mood shifts (hours) and chronic emptiness.  
- Anger/outbursts and impulsive behavior.

Other possibilities your team will consider: bipolar disorder (usually mood episodes last days–weeks and meet criteria for mania/hypomania), major depression, PTSD, substance-related problems, or other personality patterns. The ED team and psychiatry will sort this out.

Immediate steps you can expect (and things that are important now)
- A focused suicide/safety assessment: current suicidal ideation, plan, intent, prior attempts, access to means. If there’s high imminent risk you may be admitted for safety.  
- Wound care and medical treatment for injuries.  
- If safe to discharge, removal of means (knives, pills), a written safety plan, and urgent outpatient follow-up or crisis resources. In the U.S. the 988 Lifeline can be called/texted for immediate support.

Treatment and longer‑term help
- Psychotherapy is the primary treatment. Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) has the strongest evidence for reducing self‑harm and emotional dysregulation. Mentalization‑based therapy, transference‑focused psychotherapy, and schema therapy are other options.  
- Medications don’t “fix” BPD itself but can help specific symptoms (e.g., SSRIs for mood/anxiety, mood stabilizers for impulsivity/affective lability, antipsychotics for severe anger or transient psychotic symptoms). These are tailored by a psychiatrist.  
- Building a crisis/safety plan, learning emotion‑regulation and interpersonal skills, and getting regular therapy can markedly improve functioning over time.

What I recommend now
- Be honest with the ED/psychiatry team about any suicidal thoughts, plans, or access to means — this helps them keep you safe.  
- If you aren’t currently safe at home or feel you might act on suicidal thoughts, request inpatient evaluation/admission.  
- Ask for an urgent referral to DBT or a clinician experienced with BPD, and for crisis resources before discharge.  
- If you want, I can help you draft questions to ask the psychiatrist/therapist or look up DBT programs in your area.

You’ve already taken a hard step by seeking help and telling someone how you feel. If you’re in immediate danger or thinking about killing yourself, call local emergency services or a crisis line now.

question:
I am a 9-year-old boy with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. My mother brought me to the clinic because I developed itchy vesicles on the left side of my torso about 12 hours prior to the visit. The day before the vesicles appeared, I had been complaining of a burning sensation in that same area. 

For the past month, I have been undergoing chemotherapy, which includes methotrexate, cytarabine, and cyclophosphamide. My most recent treatment was just two days ago. I have no other significant medical history and, at the time of the clinic visit, I did not have a fever, and my vital signs were normal.

During the examination, the doctor noted that the painful vesicles were localized to the left C7 skin dermatome. My symptoms and the location of the vesicles were discussed, leading to considerations about the possible cause of my skin lesions.
options: A. Viral infection of the skin B. Reactivation of the varicella zoster virus (VZV) due to congenital immunodeficiency C. Chickenpox D. Reactivation of VZV due to immunodeficiency caused by chemotherapy E. Bacterial infection of the skin
solution_text: Reactivation of VZV due to immunodeficiency caused by chemotherapy
default:
Most likely diagnosis: herpes zoster (shingles) from reactivation of varicella‑zoster virus. The burning pain followed a day later by grouped vesicles in a single dermatome (left C7) and the fact that he is immunosuppressed from recent chemotherapy strongly support this.

Why this matters
- Immunosuppression (chemotherapy) raises the risk of VZV reactivation and of more severe or widespread disease. Prompt antiviral treatment lowers the risk of complications.

Recommended next steps (what the clinic/hospital should do now)
1. Start antiviral therapy immediately — in an immunocompromised child this is typically intravenous acyclovir (10 mg/kg IV every 8 hours; duration usually 7–10 days, adjusted by the treating team). Discuss and confirm exact dosing with the pediatric oncology/infectious‑disease team.
2. Collect a sample from a fresh vesicle for VZV PCR (best test) to confirm the diagnosis. A Tzanck smear can show viral changes but is not specific.
3. Isolation precautions: airborne and contact precautions until lesions are crusted to prevent spread (especially to pregnant women, newborns, and other immunocompromised people).
4. Notify the oncology team immediately — they will decide whether admission, adjustment of chemo, or additional therapies are needed and will monitor for dissemination (new lesions outside the dermatome, fever, respiratory or neurologic signs).
5. Symptom control: pain management (age‑appropriate analgesics; avoid aspirin) and wound care. Discuss options for neuropathic pain if needed with specialists.
6. Watch for signs of worsening (fever, many new lesions beyond the dermatome, breathing or neurologic symptoms) — these require urgent evaluation.

Other considerations
- Differential diagnoses (less likely given the presentation) include herpes simplex or other vesicular rashes, but the dermatomal distribution and prodromal burning are classic for zoster.
- In some high‑risk patients, antiviral prophylaxis is used during chemotherapy — this would be discussed by his oncology team going forward.

If you want, I can write a short note you can give to the oncology team/emergency staff stating the suspected diagnosis and urgent recommendation for IV acyclovir.

question:
I am a 49-year-old man who has generally been in good health. Recently, I began experiencing worsening headaches that persisted for about a month. Alongside the headaches, I noticed an increase in my irritability. Concerned about these symptoms, I decided to visit my physician for an examination.

During the visit, the doctor conducted a thorough examination and noted bilateral papilledema in my eyes. To investigate further, I underwent an MRI of my brain. The results showed a mass located in the right temporal lobe, characterized by heterogeneous peripheral rim enhancement that crossed the midline.

Following the diagnosis, I was scheduled for a surgical resection of the mass. The surgery took place successfully, and the gross examination of the mass revealed it to be poorly demarcated, with visible areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. I am now awaiting the microscopic examination results of the mass to understand more about its nature and implications for my health.
options: A. Spindle cells with hypercellular and hypocellular regions B. Closely-packed capillaries and foamy stromal cells C. Pleomorphic cells forming pseudopalisades D. Cells with clear cytoplasm and central round nuclei E. Small blue cells arranged in rosettes F. Areas of lamellated calcification
default:
Given your age, clinical course (rapidly progressive headaches, papilledema), imaging (right temporal, heterogeneously rim-enhancing mass that crosses the midline) and the gross description (poorly demarcated with hemorrhage and necrosis), the most likely diagnosis is glioblastoma (glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV), most often the primary (IDH‑wildtype) form in adults.

What the pathologist will likely report microscopically
- Highly cellular, infiltrative astrocytic tumor with marked nuclear pleomorphism and atypia.  
- Frequent mitotic figures.  
- Necrosis with pseudopalisading of tumor cells around necrotic foci (a characteristic feature).  
- Microvascular proliferation / endothelial proliferation.  
- High proliferative index (Ki‑67/MIB‑1).  
- Tumor cells usually express GFAP (glial fibrillary acidic protein), confirming glial origin.

Typical molecular tests and why they matter
- IDH1/IDH2 mutation status: most primary GBMs are IDH‑wildtype; IDH‑mutant GBMs (less common in older adults) have a better prognosis.  
- MGMT promoter methylation: predicts better response to temozolomide chemotherapy.  
- Other common alterations (often reported): EGFR amplification, TERT promoter mutation, combined chromosome 7 gain/10 loss — these support the diagnosis and prognosis.

Next steps and prognosis
- Standard management after maximal safe resection is concurrent radiotherapy with temozolomide followed by adjuvant temozolomide (Stupp protocol).  
- Prognosis is guarded; median survival for glioblastoma with current standard therapy is on the order of about 12–18 months, but individual outcomes vary and MGMT methylation/IDH status influence prognosis.  
- You should expect a formal pathology report within a few days that includes the microscopic description and molecular test results; discuss those results and adjuvant treatment options with your neurosurgeon and neuro‑oncology team.

If you’d like, tell me the microscopic/pathology report when you get it and I can help explain the terms and implications.

question:
I am a 39-year-old woman with a history of migraine headaches. Recently, I experienced a sudden and severe throbbing headache that began an hour before I arrived at the emergency room. Alongside the headache, I noticed that I was also experiencing double vision. 

In the weeks leading up to this event, I had been having frequent headaches and realized that I hadn’t had my period for several months. Upon arrival at the hospital, my blood pressure was recorded at 93/61 mm Hg. During the visual field testing, it was noted that I had decreased visual acuity and a loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. 

The combination of these symptoms prompted further evaluation to determine the underlying cause.
options: A. Transient ischemic attack B. Pituitary apoplexy C. Sheehan syndrome D. Migraine with aura E. Subarachnoid hemorrhage F. Cluster headache
default:
This presentation is most consistent with pituitary apoplexy — sudden hemorrhage or infarction of a pituitary adenoma.

Why this fits
- Acute severe (“worst”) headache and diplopia are classic for apoplexy.
- Bitemporal peripheral visual field loss = compression of the optic chiasm by an enlarging pituitary mass.
- Months of amenorrhea beforehand suggest a preexisting pituitary adenoma (eg, prolactinoma or nonfunctioning adenoma).
- Low BP can reflect acute secondary adrenal insufficiency from loss of ACTH production.

Immediate next steps (urgent)
1. Treat presumptively for adrenal crisis: IV glucocorticoids (eg, hydrocortisone bolus 100 mg IV, then intermittent dosing or infusion) and IV fluids while workup proceeds. Do not give thyroid hormone before steroids if central adrenal insufficiency is possible.
2. Urgent MRI pituitary/sellar protocol (CT if MRI not immediately available) to confirm hemorrhage/enlargement.
3. STAT labs: serum cortisol and ACTH, TSH and free T4, prolactin, LH/FSH, basic metabolic panel (sodium), glucose.
4. Neurosurgery and endocrine consultations promptly — transsphenoidal decompression is often needed for progressive visual loss or neurologic deterioration.
5. Ophthalmology/visual field testing and ongoing hemodynamic support as needed.

Prognosis
- With rapid steroids and appropriate neurosurgical/endocrine care, vision and ophthalmoplegia often improve. Long-term pituitary hormone deficiencies are common and may require lifelong replacement.

If this is happening now or very recently, make sure ED staff know you may have pituitary apoplexy so steroids, urgent MRI, and neurosurgical consult are started immediately.

question:
I am a 12-year-old African American boy who experienced a severe and painful penile erection for about five hours. This incident occurred while I was attending class at school when my penis suddenly became erect without any obvious reason. 

After the pain became unbearable, my parents took me to the emergency room for evaluation. The medical team conducted several tests to understand what was happening. They performed a complete blood count and a cavernous blood gas analysis. 

During my time in the ER, I was in significant discomfort, and the doctors decided to use an aspiration technique to relieve the pressure and pain. They also administered an adrenergic agonist along with pain relief medication. Fortunately, this approach was effective, and I experienced rapid detumescence.

The medical staff discussed various potential causes for my condition, considering my age and the nature of the symptoms. While I was able to express my discomfort, the focus was on diagnosing the underlying issue to prevent any future occurrences. The entire experience was quite alarming, but I was relieved when the treatment began to work.
options: A. Sickle cell disease (SCD) B. Glucose-6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) D. Hereditary spherocytosis E. Thalassemia
default:
What you described is called priapism — a painful, unwanted erection that doesn’t go away after a normal period. Based on how it happened and the tests/treatment you had, this was most likely ischemic (low‑flow) priapism, which is the painful kind and a medical emergency.

Why the doctors did what they did
- Cavernous blood gas: this checks the oxygen and carbon dioxide levels inside the penis. In ischemic priapism the blood is low in oxygen, high in CO2, and acidic.  
- Aspiration and irrigation: removing blood from the penis relieves pressure and pain.  
- Adrenergic agonist (most often phenylephrine): this medicine helps the blood vessels squeeze down so normal blood flow returns.  
Those steps are the standard, correct emergency treatment and it’s good that they worked quickly for you.

Common causes, especially in someone your age
- Sickle cell disease is the most common cause in boys of African descent.  
- Other causes can include blood disorders, some medicines or drugs, or rarely trauma.  
If you don’t already know your sickle cell status, your doctors will likely want to check for it (hemoglobin electrophoresis) and may do more blood tests or refer you to a hematologist.

What to expect next and follow‑up
- Because it was treated after about five hours, the chance of full recovery is good, but follow-up is important.  
- You should see a urologist and possibly a hematologist to find the cause and to make a plan to prevent recurrence.  
- If priapism lasts much longer (generally over 24 hours) there is a higher risk of permanent damage to erectile tissue; quick treatment lowers that risk.  
- If you ever have another erection that is painful and lasts more than 3–4 hours, go to the ER right away.

If you want, tell me whether you already know if you have sickle cell disease or trait, and whether the ER gave you any lab numbers (like the blood gas results). I can help explain what those numbers mean or what your next appointments might involve.

question:
I am a 58-year-old man who visited my physician due to a burning pain in my neck and arms that has persisted for about a year. During this time, I also experienced tingling sensations, or paresthesias, in my hands. Over the past three months, I noticed a gradual increase in weakness in both of my hands.

I have a history of type 2 diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. Three years ago, I was involved in a motor vehicle collision, but I haven't had any significant issues since then. My current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin.

In terms of my sexual history, I have had seven partners throughout my life, and I have used condoms inconsistently. During my examination, I was oriented to time, place, and person, and my vital signs were within normal limits. The doctor noted that my pupils were equal and reactive to light.

When examining my upper extremities, the doctor found decreased muscle strength, absent reflexes, and a weakened hand grip, accompanied by fasciculations in both arms. Sensation to temperature and pain was absent over my chest and the upper arms, though I could still feel vibration and joint position in my upper limbs. The examination of my lower extremities showed no abnormalities.
options: A. Tabes dorsalis B. Cervical disk prolapse C. Amytrophic lateral sclerosis D. Brown-Séquard syndrome E. Multiple sclerosis F. Subacute combined degeneration G. Syringomyelia
default:
Most likely diagnosis: syringomyelia (a cervical spinal cord syrinx), probably post‑traumatic given your remote motor vehicle collision.

Why: your pattern — loss of pain and temperature over the chest/upper arms in a “cape‑like” distribution with preservation of vibration/position sense, plus progressive bilateral hand weakness, absent upper‑extremity reflexes and fasciculations — is classic for a fluid‑filled cavity in the central spinal cord. A syrinx damages the crossing spinothalamic fibers in the anterior commissure (explaining bilateral pain/temp loss) and the anterior horn cells (explaining LMN signs, atrophy, fasciculations, and weakness). Diabetic peripheral neuropathy, cervical radiculopathy, or ALS are less consistent with this exact sensory pattern and combination of signs.

Recommended next steps
- Urgent MRI of the cervical (and thoracic) spine with attention to syrinx; MRI brain if concern for Chiari malformation.  
- Neurosurgery referral if a syrinx is confirmed (treatment options include shunting or addressing an underlying lesion).  
- EMG/NCS if there is uncertainty or to document anterior horn vs peripheral nerve involvement.  
- Symptomatic management: neuropathic pain agents (e.g., gabapentin/pregabalin, duloxetine/TCAs), physiotherapy, and optimal diabetes and cardiovascular risk control.

If you want, I can summarize what an MRI report would look like if a syrinx is present and outline likely treatment options and prognosis.

question: I am a 35-year-old male who recently visited the emergency department due to experiencing hemoptysis. During my evaluation, a chest X-ray was performed, which showed bilateral focal pulmonary consolidation. Upon further questioning by the medical staff, I also disclosed that I had been noticing hematuria. They conducted a urinalysis, which revealed the presence of red blood cell casts, and I was informed that I had excreted 400 mL of urine over a 24-hour period. The medical team began to consider the possible causes for both my hemoptysis and hematuria.
options: A. Anti-Smith antibodies B. Anti-neutrophil antibodies C. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies D. Anti-nuclear antibodies E. Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies
default:
Your combination of hemoptysis, bilateral pulmonary consolidation, RBC casts on urinalysis, and oliguria (400 mL/24 h) strongly suggests a pulmonary–renal syndrome (simultaneous lung hemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). The two highest‑priority considerations are:

- Anti‑GBM (Goodpasture) disease — classically causes alveolar hemorrhage (hemoptysis) plus rapidly progressive GN with RBC casts and oliguria. Renal biopsy shows linear IgG deposition along the GBM. Anti‑GBM antibody testing is diagnostic.
- ANCA‑associated vasculitides (granulomatosis with polyangiitis or microscopic polyangiitis) — can present similarly (pulmonary hemorrhage + pauci‑immune crescentic GN). Test with ANCA (c‑ANCA/PR3, p‑ANCA/MPO).

Other less likely causes: severe SLE (diffuse alveolar hemorrhage + lupus nephritis), infective endocarditis with immune complex GN, cryoglobulinemia or other vasculitides, or drug/toxin‑induced causes.

What should be done urgently
- Admit and consult nephrology and pulmonology immediately.
- Urgent labs: serum creatinine/BUN, electrolytes, CBC, coagulation profile, blood type & crossmatch, urinalysis with microscopy (already RBC casts), urine protein quantification.
- Specific serologies: anti‑GBM antibodies, ANCA (PR3, MPO), ANA/anti‑dsDNA, complement levels. Blood and sputum cultures if infection suspected.
- Imaging/diagnostics: chest CT for better lung detail; consider bronchoscopy with BAL if alveolar hemorrhage uncertain or to exclude infection.
- Renal biopsy (urgent) to establish type of GN if safe and feasible.
- Empiric, time‑sensitive treatment if clinical suspicion is high: high‑dose IV corticosteroids and prompt immunosuppression (nephrology guidance). If anti‑GBM is likely/confirmed, plasmapheresis is indicated urgently to remove circulating antibodies. For ANCA vasculitis, cyclophosphamide or rituximab plus steroids is standard.
- Avoid anticoagulation unless absolutely required and infection should be excluded before heavy immunosuppression.

Bottom line: This presentation is an emergency typical of anti‑GBM disease or ANCA‑associated pulmonary‑renal syndrome. Rapid diagnostic testing (anti‑GBM, ANCA, renal biopsy) and urgent treatment (steroids, possible plasmapheresis and immunosuppression) are needed. Contact your treating team now if not already started.

question:
I am a 45-year-old woman who has been experiencing a range of symptoms for the past two years. I have been feeling fatigued and have dealt with bouts of paresthesia, which manifest as a tingling sensation in my hands and legs. This tingling occurs in a glove and stocking pattern and is sometimes accompanied by a burning sensation.

Additionally, I have had 2 to 3 episodes of non-bloody diarrhea each month, which are associated with crampy abdominal pain. My past medical history is unremarkable, and I do not smoke, consume alcohol, or use illicit drugs.

During a recent medical evaluation, my vital signs were recorded as follows: blood pressure was 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 92 beats per minute, respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute, and my temperature was normal at 37.0°C (98.6°F). A blood test revealed low hemoglobin levels and a high mean corpuscular volume, along with other notable findings. A peripheral blood smear indicated hypersegmented neutrophils. I also underwent an upper GI series with a small bowel follow-through, which showed a narrowing in the terminal ileum.

As I reflect on my symptoms and the results from the tests, I am left seeking a diagnosis that can explain these ongoing health issues.
options: A. Pernicious anemia B. Celiac disease C. Crohn's disease D. Bacterial overgrowth E. Hypothyroidism
default:
Most likely diagnosis: Crohn disease with terminal-ileal involvement causing vitamin B12 malabsorption → vitamin B12 deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) and peripheral neuropathy.

Why this fits
- Macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils = megaloblastic anemia (classically B12 or folate deficiency).  
- Neurologic symptoms (glove-and-stocking paresthesias, burning) are typical of B12 deficiency.  
- Narrowing of the terminal ileum on small-bowel study strongly suggests Crohn disease; the terminal ileum is where B12–intrinsic factor complexes are absorbed, so ileal disease causes B12 malabsorption.  
- Intermittent nonbloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain are common Crohn features.

Recommended next steps
1. Urgently check serum B12, methylmalonic acid (MMA) and homocysteine (MMA is most specific for B12 deficiency).  
2. Start B12 replacement without delay if clinically suspected (intramuscular cyanocobalamin/hydroxocobalamin is typical) to reduce risk of irreversible neurologic damage.  
3. Refer to gastroenterology for colonoscopy with ileoscopy and biopsy to confirm Crohn disease, and further workup (CRP/ESR, fecal calprotectin, stool studies as indicated).  
4. Evaluate for other nutritional deficiencies (folate, iron) and consider imaging/endoscopic therapy and Crohn-directed treatment (steroids, immunomodulators, biologics) based on severity.  
5. Consider testing for anti–intrinsic factor/parietal cell antibodies only if ileal disease is absent or if the picture remains unclear.

If you like, I can: (a) draft specific tests and values to request, (b) outline an immediate B12 replacement regimen, or (c) give questions to ask your gastroenterologist.

question:
I am a 59-year-old woman and recently visited an urgent care clinic due to severe abdominal pain that had lasted for the past two hours. Along with this pain, I experienced a dull ache in my back and felt nauseous, which led to several episodes of vomiting. I noticed that the pain did not seem to be related to food intake.

My medical history includes recurrent abdominal pain attributed to cholelithiasis. Additionally, I am aware that my father passed away at the age of 60 due to some form of abdominal cancer. During my visit, my vital signs were recorded: my temperature was normal, my respirations were steady, my pulse was at 67 beats per minute, and my blood pressure measured 122 over 98.

The physical examination did not reveal any significant findings. However, a CT scan of my abdomen later indicated the presence of a calcified mass near my gallbladder. Given these circumstances, I understood that certain diagnoses needed to be considered and excluded.
options: A. Acute cholecystitis B. Gallbladder cancer C. Choledocholithiasis D. Pancreatitis E. Duodenal peptic ulcer
default:
You are right to be thinking about biliary and pancreatic causes given your history of gallstones, the severe epigastric/upper abdominal pain radiating to the back, nausea/vomiting, and a calcified mass seen near the gallbladder on CT. Key diagnoses that should be considered and actively excluded are:

Most likely / urgent to exclude
- Gallstone pancreatitis — classically causes severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back with nausea/vomiting. Check serum lipase (best test). If elevated, treat as pancreatitis (NPO, IV fluids, pain control) and evaluate for gallstone etiology.
- Acute cholecystitis (acute inflammation of the gallbladder) — may be subtle on exam; ultrasound and HIDA scan help confirm. If present, often needs early surgical treatment.
- Choledocholithiasis / ascending cholangitis — stones in the common bile duct can cause obstructive LFT pattern and, if infected, cause fever, jaundice, hypotension/altered mental status (Reynolds’ pentad). Check LFTs, bilirubin; if suspected, MRCP or ERCP may be needed.

Findings on CT to clarify
- “Calcified mass near the gallbladder” may represent a calcified gallstone or a calcified gallbladder wall (porcelain gallbladder). Porcelain gallbladder is associated with chronic cholecystitis and has a higher long-term risk of gallbladder cancer, so it is generally an indication for cholecystectomy in a reasonable surgical candidate.
- Less commonly the calcification could be a calcified lymph node, hepatic calcification, or other benign calcifications; further imaging helps characterize it.

Recommended next steps / tests
- Serum lipase (rule out pancreatitis)
- Liver tests (AST, ALT, ALP, bilirubin) and CBC, CMP
- Right upper quadrant ultrasound (better for gallstones and gallbladder wall assessment)
- If ultrasound is equivocal for acute cholecystitis: HIDA scan
- If common bile duct stone is suspected or LFTs are obstructive: MRCP or ERCP (therapeutic)
- If porcelain gallbladder or concern for malignancy on imaging: surgical referral and consideration of contrast-enhanced CT or MRI and hepatobiliary surgical evaluation

Management implications
- If pancreatitis: admit, supportive care; if gallstone-related, cholecystectomy is often done during the same hospitalization or shortly after recovery.
- If acute cholecystitis: antibiotics and early cholecystectomy in most patients.
- If porcelain gallbladder seen on imaging: elective cholecystectomy is usually recommended because of malignancy risk (discuss options with a surgeon).
- If imaging suggests cancer: referral to hepatobiliary surgery/oncology for staging and management.

When to seek emergency care now
- New/worsening fever, jaundice, increasing or unremitting pain, lightheadedness, or inability to keep fluids down — go to the emergency department.

Bring your CT images and any prior imaging to your surgeon or gastroenterologist. If you’d like, tell me the exact CT wording (radiology report) or upload the report/text of the imaging and labs you already have and I can help interpret what the radiologist meant and advise next steps.

question:
I am a 68-year-old man who recently visited the emergency department due to difficulty breathing that had persisted for the past two days. Over the last six months, I have experienced recurrent episodes of bacterial pneumonia in my right lower lobe, with the most recent episode beginning seven days ago, for which I am currently receiving antibiotic treatment. 

I have a significant smoking history of 35 pack-years and also have a medical history of hypertension, for which I take lisinopril. During my physical examination, the healthcare provider noted decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion in the base of my right lung. 

To further investigate my condition, a chest X-ray was performed, revealing a large pleural effusion on the right side. A subsequent chest CT scan showed a substantial mass near the hilum of my right lung. Additionally, a cytologic examination of the pleural fluid indicated the presence of malignancy. 

I understand that these findings require further evaluation to determine the most likely diagnosis related to my condition.
options: A. Pulmonary hamartoma B. Mesothelioma C. Non-small cell lung cancer D. Small cell lung cancer E. Metastatic lung disease
default:
Most likely diagnosis: squamous cell carcinoma of the right lung (a centrally located bronchogenic carcinoma) causing bronchial obstruction with recurrent post‑obstructive pneumonia and a malignant pleural effusion (which makes this metastatic/Stage IV disease).

Why this fits:
- Long smoking history and age increase lung cancer risk.  
- Recurrent pneumonia in the same right lower lobe suggests airway obstruction by a central tumor.  
- CT shows a hilar mass (typical location for squamous cell or small‑cell, squamous is most classically associated with smoking and post‑obstructive infection).  
- Malignant cells in pleural fluid indicate pleural involvement (M1a).

Recommended next steps:
- Obtain tissue diagnosis and histologic subtype (bronchoscopic biopsy of the hilar lesion or CT‑guided biopsy if peripheral components). Pleural biopsy can also help if pleural cytology is nondiagnostic.  
- Staging with PET‑CT and brain MRI to guide therapy.  
- Symptomatic management of the effusion (therapeutic thoracentesis; consider pleurodesis if recurrent).  
- Prompt referral to pulmonology and medical oncology to discuss systemic therapy (and targeted/immunotherapy options if appropriate) and possible local treatments.

If you’d like, I can explain the differences among lung cancer types, expected tests for staging, or what treatment options might be given your likely diagnosis.

question:
I am a 37-year-old woman, currently 35 weeks pregnant with my second child. I arrived at the emergency department due to continuous dark vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain, which started about an hour prior. My first child was delivered via a lower segment transverse cesarean section due to a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. 

I have a history of hypertension and have not been compliant with my medication regimen. Currently, I take methyldopa, folic acid, and a multivitamin. Upon examination, my pulse was recorded at 90 beats per minute, my respirations at 16 breaths per minute, and my blood pressure was 145 over 90. The physician noted that my abdomen was tender, and I was experiencing hypertonic contractions. There was visible blood on the vulva, around the introitus, and on the medial aspect of both thighs. 

The fetus was found to be in a breech presentation, and the fetal heart rate was elevated at 180 beats per minute, with recurrent decelerations observed. The medical team assessed my condition and the potential causes of fetal compromise based on these findings.
options: A. Rupture of the uterus B. Placental tissue covering the cervical os C. Rupture of aberrant fetal vessels D. Abnormal position of the fetus E. Detachment of the placenta
default:
Summary diagnosis — most likely placental abruption (abruptio placentae) causing uteroplacental insufficiency and acute fetal compromise.

Why this fits
- Risk factors present: untreated/poorly controlled hypertension is a major risk factor for abruption.  
- Classic findings: sudden onset abdominal pain, a tender/board‑like hypertonic uterus, and dark vaginal bleeding are typical for abruption (vs placenta previa which is usually painless, bright red bleeding).  
- Fetal signs: persistent fetal tachycardia (180 bpm) with recurrent decelerations indicates significant fetal distress from acute uteroplacental bleeding/insufficiency.  
- Concealed hemorrhage is common in abruption and can explain blood seen on the vulva/thighs while the uterus is tense and tender.

Other considerations (differential)
- Uterine rupture (higher risk because of prior cesarean): can present with severe pain, abnormal fetal heart tracings and bleeding — less classic here but must be considered, especially if sudden loss of station, cessation of contractions, or maternal instability.  
- Umbilical cord prolapse or compression can cause recurrent decelerations, particularly with malpresentation (breech), but usually occurs with membrane rupture and produces sudden profound variable decelerations; it does not explain a tense, tender uterus.  
- Infection (chorioamnionitis) can cause fetal tachycardia but usually has fever, maternal tachycardia and no acute uterine tenderness/hypertonus.

Immediate management priorities (what the team should do now)
- Call obstetrics/OR and neonatal team immediately — this is an obstetric emergency.  
- Maternal stabilization: two large‑bore IV lines, type & crossmatch, full blood count, coagulation studies, and urgent blood products available.  
- Continuous fetal monitoring and close maternal vital sign monitoring. Place patient in left lateral tilt, give oxygen if fetal distress severe, and treat severe hypertension acutely (IV labetalol or hydralazine per local protocol).  
- Prepare for urgent delivery — with prior lower segment cesarean, breech presentation and ongoing fetal compromise, emergency cesarean delivery is the usual course. If uterine rupture is suspected, immediate laparotomy.  
- Avoid tocolysis. If coagulopathy or heavy hemorrhage develops, treat with blood products and correct DIC as needed. Neonatal resuscitation team should be present at delivery.

Bottom line: the most likely cause of the fetal distress in your case is placental abruption related to poorly controlled hypertension; urgent stabilization and expedited delivery (most likely emergency cesarean) are required. If you’d like, I can explain the steps of the cesarean, risks to you and the baby, or what to expect in the immediate postpartum period.

question:
I arrived at the emergency department after experiencing severe lower chest pain that had persisted for the past hour. The pain radiated to my back and was accompanied by nausea. Since the onset of the pain, I had vomited twice, though the vomit was non-bloody.

I have a medical history that includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Additionally, I have been a smoker for 30 years, consuming one pack of cigarettes daily. My alcohol intake is around five to six beers per day. At the time of my visit, I was taking enalapril and metformin as part of my treatment.

Upon examination, I was noted to have a fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F), a pulse of 110 beats per minute, and my blood pressure was measured at 90/60 mm Hg. The examination revealed clear lungs, but my abdomen was distended with tenderness and guarding in the epigastric region—though there was no rebound tenderness. My bowel sounds were decreased.

The medical staff conducted several assessments, including an ECG, which indicated sinus tachycardia. I was concerned about what might be causing my symptoms and awaited further evaluation and diagnosis.
options: A. Acute mesenteric ischemia B. Boerhaave syndrome C. Aortic dissection D. Peptic ulcer disease E. Pericarditis F. Myocardial infarction G. Acute pancreatitis
default:
What this most likely is
- Your story (sudden severe epigastric/lower chest pain radiating to the back, nausea/vomiting, alcohol use, fever, abdominal distention/tenderness with decreased bowel sounds, hypotension and tachycardia) is most consistent with acute pancreatitis — very likely alcohol-related. The classic features are severe epigastric pain radiating to the back plus vomiting and abdominal tenderness. The fever, low blood pressure and tachycardia are concerning for a severe attack and systemic inflammatory response (SIRS) or evolving shock.

Why it isn’t certain yet
- Confirmation requires testing (see below). Other causes to consider and exclude early are myocardial ischemia, perforated viscus, pulmonary embolus or aortic pathology, so the team will usually check troponin, chest X‑ray/ECG (you had ECG), and other tests as indicated.

What I’d expect the ED to do next (immediate priorities)
1. Diagnostic tests
   - Serum lipase (and/or amylase) — lipase >3× upper limit strongly supports pancreatitis.
   - Basic labs: CBC, electrolytes, BUN/creatinine, glucose, liver tests, calcium, serum triglycerides, lactate.
   - Cardiac troponin (to exclude myocardial ischemia given chest pain and hypotension).
   - Blood cultures only if febrile and suspected infection.
   - Abdominal ultrasound (RUQ) to look for gallstones/biliary obstruction.
   - Contrast CT abdomen only if diagnosis is uncertain or to assess severity/complications.

2. Supportive treatment (start immediately)
   - NPO (nothing by mouth).
   - Aggressive IV fluids (isotonic crystalloid). Initial bolus then frequent reassessment — patients with hypotension often need prompt resuscitation and ICU-level monitoring.
   - Analgesia (IV opioids as needed).
   - Antiemetics for nausea/vomiting.
   - Oxygen if hypoxic; monitor urine output and vital signs frequently.
   - Hold metformin while hypotensive/if renal function is impaired (risk of lactic acidosis).
   - Temporarily hold ACE inhibitor if hypotension persists; address blood pressure once fluids given.

3. Disposition and escalation
   - Because of hypotension and tachycardia plus fever, the ED may transfer you to an ICU or high-dependency unit for close monitoring, aggressive fluids, and possible vasopressors if blood pressure does not respond.
   - If gallstone pancreatitis with signs of cholangitis or biliary obstruction, urgent ERCP may be required.
   - If triglycerides are very high (>1000 mg/dL), specific therapy (insulin/plasmapheresis) may be needed.
   - Antibiotics are not given routinely for acute pancreatitis unless there is documented infected necrosis or another clear source of infection.

Potential complications to watch for
- Pancreatic necrosis/infection, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury, shock, pseudocyst formation, and persistent organ failure.

What you should know now
- The ED should be working on the blood tests and imaging now and treating you with fluids, pain control, and monitoring. The final diagnosis will depend largely on the lipase level and imaging. Given your alcohol history and the exam, pancreatitis is the leading possibility and needs prompt, aggressive management.

If you’d like, tell me the lab or imaging results when they become available and I can help interpret them and explain next steps.

question:
I am an 11-year-old boy who was brought to the emergency department after I was found screaming and clutching my head. This incident occurred about 30 minutes before arriving at the hospital. For the past week, I have been experiencing nausea and occasional vomiting. Additionally, I have had a fever and left-sided headaches for the past two weeks, along with increasing tooth pain over the last three weeks. 

When I got to the hospital, I was in moderate distress. The medical staff noted that my temperature was high, and my heart rate was elevated. I was confused and could only recognize people, not where I was. They observed that my pupils reacted slowly to light. During the examination, they found signs of swelling in my optic nerves. Although my eye movements were normal, they noticed that bending my neck caused flexion in my hips. The doctors were trying to determine what was causing these symptoms and what my diagnosis might be.
options: A. Viral meningitis B. Medulloblastoma C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage D. HSV encephalitis E. Pyogenic brain abscess F. Cavernous sinus thrombosis
default:
Most likely you have a brain abscess (a pocket of infection in the brain) that developed from your infected tooth. The story fits: weeks of tooth pain followed by left-sided headache, fever and nausea for days to weeks, then sudden worsening with severe headache and confusion. The swollen optic nerves (papilledema) mean raised pressure inside your head, and bending your neck causing your hips to flex is a sign of meningeal irritation (like meningitis can cause) — both can occur when an abscess or other infection spreads in the skull.

Why this is most likely:
- Dental infections can spread directly or through the blood to the brain.
- A brain abscess often causes a gradually worsening headache, fever, vomiting, altered mental status and signs of raised intracranial pressure.
- Eye movements being preserved makes a cavernous sinus thrombosis less likely, while the positive meningeal sign and papilledema point to an intracranial space‑occupying infection.

What should happen next (urgent steps):
- Immediate brain imaging (contrast CT or MRI) to look for an abscess or subdural empyema.
- Do NOT have a lumbar puncture until imaging shows it is safe (because high intracranial pressure can make LP dangerous).
- Start broad‑spectrum IV antibiotics that cover oral bacteria and anaerobes (and add MRSA coverage if needed) and get neurosurgery involved for possible drainage.

If you want, I can explain what the imaging will look for, what antibiotics are typically used, and how a brain abscess is treated and recovered from.

question:
At 20 days old, I was brought to the emergency department by my parents due to concerns about my lethargy and easy bruising. My mother noticed that I had been eating less over the past few days, and on the day of our visit, I was difficult to arouse. Typically, I nurse four to five times a day, but I had eaten less the day before and that morning. 

I was born at 39 weeks gestation through a spontaneous vaginal delivery at home, and my parents had provided minimal prenatal and postnatal care. This was my first time visiting a physician. During the evaluation, my family was asked several questions to rule out child abuse. The medical team documented my vital signs: my pulse was 97 beats per minute, my respirations were 35 breaths per minute, my temperature was 35.8°C (96.4°F), and my blood pressure was recorded at 71/46 mm Hg. A physical examination revealed diffuse petechiae and bruising on my skin.
options: A. Group B streptococcus (GBS) infection B. Hepatitis B infection C. Thyroid stimulating hormone deficiency D. Vitamin D deficiency E. Vitamin K deficiency
default:
Most likely diagnosis
- Vitamin K–deficiency bleeding (hemorrhagic disease of the newborn), most consistent with late VKDB (age 2–12 weeks) from lack of prophylactic vitamin K after a home birth.

Why
- Newborns have low vitamin K stores and breast milk contains little vitamin K. Without prophylaxis at birth they are at risk for bleeding from deficiency of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X). Presentation can include poor feeding, lethargy, hypotension and widespread bleeding/bruising; intracranial hemorrhage is common in late VKDB.

Key diagnostic clues and labs
- Prolonged PT/INR (often the earliest abnormality, because factor VII has the shortest half‑life). PTT may be prolonged later. Platelet count and fibrinogen are usually normal (helps distinguish from DIC or thrombocytopenic causes of petechiae). Administering vitamin K corrects the coagulopathy over hours.

Immediate management
1. Stabilize (airway, breathing, circulation).  
2. Obtain labs: CBC, PT/INR, PTT, fibrinogen, blood type/crossmatch; consider blood cultures if sepsis possible.  
3. Give vitamin K (phytonadione) promptly (neonatal treatment dose commonly 1–2 mg; route depends on situation — IV slow or IM).  
4. For severe bleeding/shock or intracranial hemorrhage: give blood products (FFP or prothrombin-complex concentrate) to correct clotting factors immediately while vitamin K takes effect, and consider neurosurgical/neuroradiologic evaluation (head CT/MRI).  
5. If platelet count is low, give platelets as indicated.

Prevention and counseling
- Routine prophylaxis with 1 mg vitamin K IM at birth prevents this condition; ensure parents and future births receive/understand this.

question:
I am a 27-year-old man who recently experienced a two-week period marked by fever, malaise, and occasional diarrhea. Concerned about my symptoms, I sought medical attention. During the physical examination, the physician observed that I had enlarged inguinal lymph nodes. 

As part of the evaluation, I underwent an HIV screening test, which returned positive. Following this, further laboratory studies revealed that my CD4+ count was 650/mm3. Based on this information, my healthcare provider discussed my condition with me, indicating that I am likely in an early stage of HIV infection. 

I appreciate the thoroughness of the examination and the clarity during our discussion about my health.
options: A. Latent HIV infection B. Chronic HIV infection C. AIDS D. Acute HIV infection E. Asymptomatic HIV infection
default:
Thanks — and good that you sought care early. Briefly, here’s what your results likely mean and the usual next steps.

What this means
- A positive screening test needs confirmatory testing (most clinics do a 4th‑generation antigen/antibody test followed by an HIV‑1/HIV‑2 differentiation assay and, if needed, an HIV RNA test).  
- A CD4+ count of 650 cells/mm3 is within the normal/near‑normal range (normal roughly 500–1,500), so you are not immunosuppressed and do not have AIDS. Your symptoms are consistent with acute (early) HIV infection, which commonly causes fever, malaise, lymphadenopathy and diarrhea a few weeks after exposure.

Important next steps your clinic will likely do or discuss
- Confirmatory testing (if not already done).  
- Baseline labs: HIV viral load (RNA), genotype/resistance testing, CBC, CMP, fasting lipids/glucose, hepatitis B and C serologies, syphilis and other STI screening, and TB screening.  
- Tests that guide treatment choice: HLA‑B*5701 (if abacavir may be considered) and pregnancy test if relevant.  
- Start antiretroviral therapy (ART). Current guidelines recommend offering ART immediately regardless of CD4 count because it protects your immune system and rapidly reduces infectiousness (U=U: undetectable = untransmittable). Many clinics use a same‑day “test and treat” approach.  
- Counseling about transmission: avoid condomless sex or needle sharing until your viral load is suppressed; notify partners so they can be tested (health departments can assist with partner services). Consider PrEP for HIV‑negative partners.  
- Vaccinations as appropriate (influenza, Tdap, HPV if indicated, hepatitis B vaccine if susceptible, etc.).

What to expect on treatment
- Viral load usually falls quickly and is typically undetectable by ~3 months for most people on effective ART. Your provider will recheck viral load and CD4 at about 4–8 weeks after starting ART and then every 3–6 months until stable.  
- With early diagnosis and consistent treatment, long‑term prognosis is excellent and life expectancy approaches that of people without HIV.

If you want, I can:
- Help you draft questions to ask your provider about ART options and side effects.  
- Explain common first‑line ART regimens and what to expect.

If you have any new or worsening symptoms, trouble accessing treatment, or concerns about disclosure/partner notification, let me know so I can point you to resources.

question:
I am a 75-year-old man who recently visited the emergency department due to persistent pain in my left thigh and calf that has lasted for the past three months. The pain occurs even when I am at rest and intensifies when I walk. I have noticed that it slightly improves when I hang my foot off the bed. 

I have a history of hypertension, which I have managed for 25 years, and I have been living with type 2 diabetes mellitus for 30 years. Additionally, I have been a smoker for 45 years, consuming 30 to 40 cigarettes daily. 

During the examination, the medical staff noted that the pulses in my femoral, popliteal, and dorsalis pedis arteries were diminished but still detectable on both sides. This examination helped the healthcare team assess my condition more thoroughly.
options: A. Critical limb ischemia B. Venous ulcer C. Raynaud’s phenomenon D. Pseudogout E. Cellulitis
default:
Your history and exam are most consistent with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) with ischemic rest pain — in other words, chronic limb ischemia that may be progressing to critical limb ischemia.

Why:
- Rest pain that worsens with walking and improves when the foot is dangled (dependent) is a classic arterial/ischemic pattern (arterial pain is worse with elevation, better when limb is dependent).
- Longstanding diabetes, long heavy smoking history and long hypertension are strong risk factors for PAD.
- Diminished femoral, popliteal and dorsalis pedis pulses on exam support an arterial blood‑flow problem.

Why this matters:
- Ischemic rest pain often indicates advanced disease and puts the limb at risk of nonhealing ulcers, infection and ultimately amputation unless revascularization or other treatment is undertaken.

Recommended next steps (urgent):
1. Urgent referral to a vascular specialist (vascular surgery or interventional radiology/angiology). This is time‑sensitive.
2. Objective testing:
   - Ankle‑brachial index (ABI) and arterial duplex ultrasound as initial noninvasive tests.
   - Cross‑sectional arterial imaging (CT angiography or MR angiography, or invasive angiography) for treatment planning.
3. If critical limb ischemia is suspected, hospital admission and expedited revascularization (endovascular angioplasty/stenting or surgical bypass) is often needed.
4. Medical management to start now:
   - Begin antiplatelet therapy (aspirin or clopidogrel) if not already taking it (confirm with your doctor).
   - Start a high‑intensity statin (if not already on one).
   - Tight glycemic and blood‑pressure control.
   - Strongly and immediately stop smoking (cessation greatly affects outcomes).
   - Pain control and careful foot care; avoid walking on painful limb if advised.
5. Monitor for complications: new or worsening ulcers, gangrene, signs of infection, loss of sensation — seek immediate care if these occur.

If you’d like, I can help you prepare a brief list of questions to bring to the vascular specialist or a one‑page summary of your history and medications to take to your appointment.

question:
I was 21 years old when I experienced a medical emergency that led to my admission to the emergency department. My roommate found me unconscious in our apartment, and I was brought to the hospital. Upon arrival, my Glasgow Coma Scale score was recorded as 3 out of 15, indicating a severe level of unconsciousness. Medical staff noted that I had dilated pupils and a high fever of 39.4℃ (103.0℉). 

During transportation to the hospital, I suffered a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which was treated with intravenous diazepam. My blood pressure was high, and they managed this with nitroglycerin. Once at the hospital, the medical team inserted a nasogastric tube for gastric lavage, and I was administered activated charcoal.

Further evaluation revealed elevated creatinine phosphatase levels and low serum bicarbonate levels. Blood and urine samples were taken to determine potential drug intoxication. The situation was critical, but the medical team responded effectively to my condition.
options: A. Cocaine B. MPTP C. PCP D. Opioid E. Marijuana
default:
Based on the signs you describe, the picture is most consistent with an acute sympathomimetic stimulant intoxication (for example cocaine, amphetamines/MDMA). Reasoning in brief:
- Dilated pupils, high blood pressure and fever fit a sympathomimetic toxidrome.
- A generalized tonic‑clonic seizure and prolonged muscle activity explain the markedly raised creatine kinase (rhabdomyolysis).
- Low serum bicarbonate reflects metabolic acidosis from seizure-related lactic acid and from muscle breakdown.
- GCS 3 indicates a very depressed level of consciousness (postictal coma or central nervous system depression after overdose), and the emergency treatments you received (IV benzodiazepine for seizure, gastric decontamination/charcoal, BP control) were appropriate initial measures.

Important consequences they would watch for and typical next steps
- Monitor serial CK, creatinine and electrolytes; aggressive IV fluids to prevent/treat acute kidney injury from rhabdomyolysis.
- Continuous cardiac monitoring and ECG (stimulants can cause arrhythmias).
- Cooling and supportive measures for hyperthermia; monitor for coagulopathy, compartment syndrome, and respiratory complications (aspiration pneumonia).
- Toxicology testing (blood/urine) to identify the agent; repeated neurologic assessments.
- Psychiatric/substance‑use evaluation before discharge if this was intentional/related to substance use.

If you want, tell me whether toxicology results were later positive or share current labs (CK trend, creatinine, ECG) and I can explain what they mean and what follow‑up care is recommended. If you still have symptoms or new problems, seek medical attention right away.

question:
I am a 51-year-old woman who recently experienced significant and unintentional weight loss. Initially, I felt content with this change since I had been struggling with my weight for some time. However, my daughter encouraged me to seek medical advice. 

I have a personal medical history that includes preeclampsia, hypertension, polycystic ovarian syndrome, and hypercholesterolemia. I currently smoke about one pack of cigarettes a day and drink a glass of wine daily, but I do not use illicit drugs now, despite having a past history of injection drug use with heroin. 

During my visit, my vital signs were assessed, revealing a temperature of 36.7°C, blood pressure of 126/74 mm Hg, a heart rate of 111 beats per minute that was irregular, and a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute. The examination showed that my pulses were bounding, and my complexion appeared pale, although my breath sounds were clear. My oxygen saturation was noted at 91% on room air. 

Further discussions with my physician revealed I was experiencing some cognitive difficulties. Laboratory results indicated an elevated leukocyte count and other abnormal levels, including lactate dehydrogenase, uric acid, and B-12. Genetic testing showed the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome. These findings were concerning, and my physician is evaluating possible diagnoses.
options: A. Acute lymphocytic leukemia B. Acute myelogenous leukemia C. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia D. Chronic myelogenous leukemia E. Hairy cell leukemia
default:
The findings are most consistent with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), a myeloproliferative neoplasm driven by the Philadelphia chromosome (t[9;22] → BCR-ABL fusion).

Why this fits
- Philadelphia chromosome/BCR-ABL is the molecular hallmark of CML (it can also appear in some ALL cases but the clinical picture here favors CML).  
- Marked leukocytosis, elevated LDH and uric acid fit high cell turnover/proliferation.  
- Elevated B12 is common in myeloproliferative disorders because of increased binding proteins and marrow activity.  
- Constitutional symptoms (weight loss, cognitive symptoms, pallor) and hypoxia/low O2 saturation can occur with high WBC counts or disease progression.

What should happen next
- Urgent hematology/oncology evaluation.  
- Confirmation and staging: peripheral blood smear, quantitative BCR‑ABL PCR, bone marrow biopsy/cytogenetics.  
- Immediate management decisions depend on severity: if there is hyperleukocytosis with leukostasis (severe dyspnea, hypoxia, neurologic symptoms), emergent cytoreduction (hydroxyurea and/or leukapheresis) may be needed.  
- Definitive therapy is with BCR‑ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors (imatinib, nilotinib, dasatinib, etc.) once diagnosis is confirmed.  
- Treat metabolic complications: lower uric acid (allopurinol or rasburicase if high risk), monitor/correct electrolytes, consider tumor lysis precautions.  
- Smoking cessation and close monitoring for infection or complications given your history.

If you haven’t already, ask your doctor for an urgent hematology referral and for explanation of immediate test results (absolute WBC, differential, peripheral smear) and whether urgent cytoreduction is required.

question:
I am a previously healthy 10-year-old boy who was brought to the emergency department after experiencing a seizure. About 15 minutes before arriving, I suddenly felt nauseous and noticed shiny lights. Shortly after, the corner of my mouth began twitching, and then my entire face followed. I let out a loud scream and lost consciousness, falling to the floor. My body jerked for about two minutes.

On the way to the hospital, I regained consciousness but felt confused and had difficulty speaking clearly for about five minutes. A week prior, I had a fever and sore throat, but those symptoms had improved after taking acetaminophen. When I arrived at the hospital, I felt lethargic and could not recall the events of the seizure. 

The medical staff checked my vital signs, which were within normal limits, and I was oriented to time, place, and person. They assessed my deep tendon reflexes, which were 2+ bilaterally. However, I experienced muscular pain when they tested the reflexes. The physical and neurologic examinations did not reveal any other abnormalities.
options:
A. Focal to bilateral tonic-clonic seizure B. Focal seizure with dyscognitive features C. Convulsive syncope D. Sydenham chorea E. Generalized myoclonic seizure F. Generalized tonic-clonic seizure
"
default:
Thanks — this sounds like a first-time seizure. Based on your description, the most likely scenario is a focal (partial) seizure that secondarily generalized:

- The “aura” (nausea and seeing shiny lights) and the initial twitching of one corner of the mouth are typical of a focal onset.  
- That then progressed to a generalized convulsion (loss of consciousness and whole-body jerking).  
- The brief postictal confusion and difficulty speaking are also typical.

What this means clinically
- This is an unprovoked, focal-onset seizure that generalized. Because it’s focal, it raises concern for an underlying focal brain problem (structural lesion, recent/remote infection, or less commonly a vascular or developmental abnormality). A simple febrile seizure is unlikely given age (10 years) and the focal features.
- The muscle pain you felt with reflex testing is most likely postictal muscle soreness from the convulsion, not an abnormal reflex finding.

Recommended immediate evaluation (what ED/neurology will usually do now)
1. Basic blood tests: finger-stick glucose immediately, then electrolytes (Na, K), Ca, Mg, renal function, liver tests, CBC, and possibly toxicology depending on history.  
2. Urgent neuroimaging: MRI brain is preferred to look for a structural cause (tumor, malformation, stroke). If MRI cannot be obtained urgently, a noncontrast head CT can be done as an initial screen. Because your seizure had focal onset, neuroimaging is strongly recommended.  
3. EEG: to look for epileptiform activity and help guide prognosis/management. Often done after you’re out of the postictal state.  
4. Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) only if there are signs of central nervous system infection or meningitis (fever now, neck stiffness, ongoing altered mental status) — your current exam doesn’t sound like that, but clinicians will decide depending on overall picture.  
5. Admission vs discharge: many centers admit children after a first seizure for observation and workup, especially with focal features. Your team will discuss this.

Treatment and follow-up
- A single, brief, self-limited unprovoked seizure usually does not require starting daily antiseizure medication immediately. Antiseizure medicine is considered if: seizures recur, EEG/MRI show high-risk features (epileptiform discharges or a structural lesion), the seizure was prolonged/status epilepticus, or if seizures would cause significant danger.  
- You should follow up with a pediatric neurologist promptly (often within days to weeks) for EEG review, MRI results, and discussion about recurrence risk and activity restrictions.  
- Safety until this is clarified: avoid unsupervised swimming/bathing, climbing or working in high places, and activities where a sudden loss of consciousness would be dangerous.

When to seek emergency care
- Any seizure that lasts more than 5 minutes, repeated seizures without recovery between them, difficulty breathing after a seizure, severe injury, or prolonged altered mental status.

Prognosis
- After a single unprovoked seizure, the chance of another seizure within 1–2 years is significant (varies, commonly quoted ~30–40%) but many children never have another. The EEG and MRI help refine this risk.

If you want, tell me: any head injury recently, family history of seizures, any medications, any drug/chemical exposure, current temperature or fever, or whether the facial twitching stayed on one side the whole time. That will help refine the likely causes and advice.

question:
I am a 72-year-old woman who arrived at the emergency department about an hour after experiencing a sudden onset of a diffuse, dull, throbbing headache. The headache felt intense and was unlike anything I had felt before. Along with the headache, I noticed that my vision became blurred, and I felt nauseous. This nausea eventually led to one episode of vomiting. 

I have a history of poorly controlled hypertension, which I know can complicate my health. Given these symptoms, I understood that it was important to seek medical attention promptly. The staff in the emergency department conducted a thorough examination, including a fundoscopic examination, to better understand what might be causing my symptoms. I was concerned about the sudden nature of my headache and the accompanying symptoms, and I hoped to find out what was happening.
options: A. Hemorrhagic lacunar stroke B. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension C. Migraine headache D. Giant cell arteritis E. Hypertensive emergency F. Epidural hematoma G. Transient ischemic attack
default:
What you describe — a sudden, very severe “worst-ever” headache that came on in seconds to minutes, with nausea, vomiting and blurred vision — is classic for a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), most often from a ruptured berry (saccular) aneurysm. Your age and poorly controlled hypertension increase the risk of serious intracranial bleeding, so this presentation is an emergency until proven otherwise.

Why SAH is suspected
- “Thunderclap” onset (sudden, maximal intensity within seconds–minutes) is highly suspicious for SAH.  
- Nausea, vomiting, visual disturbance and severe pain fit the pattern.  
- Other possibilities (less likely given the suddenness) include intracerebral hemorrhage, hypertensive emergency with encephalopathy, meningitis, or an uncommon severe migraine.

What a fundoscopic exam can show (and what it means)
- In the very acute phase of SAH the fundus is often normal. Papilledema (optic disc swelling) usually takes hours to days to develop, so its absence does not rule out raised intracranial pressure or SAH.  
- Terson syndrome: intraocular (vitreous or retinal) hemorrhages can occur with SAH and can be seen on fundoscopy; their presence supports the diagnosis and can predict a worse outcome.  
- If the ED found hypertensive retinopathy (flame hemorrhages, cotton‑wool spots, hard exudates, or disc edema), that would point to severe or malignant hypertension as an important contributor, but it doesn’t exclude SAH.

Immediate tests and steps you should expect now
1. Noncontrast head CT scan — the first and most important test. It is very sensitive for SAH, especially within the first 6 hours.  
2. If CT is negative but clinical suspicion remains high, lumbar puncture (LP) is done to look for red blood cells and xanthochromia (breakdown products of blood). LP is most informative if performed >6–12 hours after headache onset.  
3. CT angiography (CTA) or MR angiography to look for an aneurysm once bleeding is confirmed (or strongly suspected).  
4. Urgent neurosurgery / neurointerventional consultation if SAH or aneurysm is found — definitive treatment may be endovascular coiling or surgical clipping.  
5. Basic labs (CBC, coagulation profile, electrolytes), ECG, and reversal of any blood thinners if you are taking them.

Acute management you should expect in the ED/hospital
- Stabilize airway/breathing/circulation.  
- Blood‑pressure control (typically aiming for systolic BP <140–160 mm Hg depending on local protocol, avoiding hypotension).  
- Nimodipine is usually started if aneurysmal SAH is suspected (helps reduce delayed cerebral ischemia from vasospasm).  
- Analgesia, antiemetics, seizure precautions as indicated, strict bed rest with head elevation, and avoidance of straining/Valsalva.  
- No anticoagulants and reverse any anticoagulation promptly.

What to ask the team / what to expect next
- Ask for the result of the noncontrast head CT; if negative, ask whether an LP is planned.  
- If SAH is confirmed, ask about CTA/MRA and when neurosurgery/interventional radiology will be involved.  
- Ask about blood‑pressure targets and whether nimodipine will be started.

You did the right thing coming to the ED promptly. If you’d like, tell me the CT/fundoscopy results the team gives you and I can help interpret them and explain the next steps.

question:
At 23 years old, I experienced a sudden onset of fever, chills, nausea, and an urgent need to urinate frequently. These symptoms began four days ago and have progressively worsened. I have a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) that has lasted for the past six months.

When I sought medical attention, my vital signs were assessed. My temperature was recorded at 39.0°C (102.2°F), my blood pressure was 100/70 mm Hg, my pulse was 92 beats per minute, and my respiratory rate was 25 breaths per minute. During the physical examination, the doctor noted moderate tenderness in the left costovertebral angle.

The medical team conducted a urinalysis, which revealed that my urine was dark yellow and turbid. The pH was measured at 6.5 with a specific gravity of 1.026. Notably, the test showed positive nitrites and leukocyte esterase, along with a significant presence of bacteria. While there were no signs of glucose or ketones, there was a trace amount of protein in my urine.

Given these symptoms and findings, I understood that I was likely dealing with another urinary tract infection, which has been a recurring issue for me.
options: A. Pyelonephritis B. Uncomplicated cystitis C. Complicated cystitis D. UTI E. Acute obstructing nephrolithiasis
default:
Most likely diagnosis
- Acute pyelonephritis (upper UTI). Fever, chills, nausea, tachypnea, left costovertebral angle tenderness and nitrite+/leukocyte esterase+/bacteriuria on UA are classic.

Immediate next steps
1. Obtain a urine culture (and blood cultures if you’re febrile/systemic) before starting antibiotics.
2. Start empiric antibiotics promptly while awaiting culture results:
   - If you can tolerate oral meds and are hemodynamically stable: an oral fluoroquinolone (e.g., ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin) is commonly used empirically in many areas (adjust based on local resistance). 
   - If you are clinically worse, vomiting, pregnant, or at risk for complications: admit for IV therapy (e.g., ceftriaxone or an aminoglycoside ± ampicillin) and supportive care.
3. Supportive care: adequate oral fluids, antipyretics (acetaminophen), and analgesics. Monitor vitals and urine output.

Duration and tailoring
- Tailor antibiotic choice to urine culture and sensitivities. Typical treatment duration for pyelonephritis ranges from ~7–14 days depending on the agent and response. Shorter regimens (e.g., 5–7 days) may be appropriate with effective oral fluoroquinolones if clinical response is rapid.

Evaluation of recurrent UTIs
- Because you’ve had recurrent UTIs for 6 months, discuss further evaluation with your clinician:
  - Review risk factors (sexual activity, new partner, spermicides, diaphragm use, incomplete voiding, diabetes, indwelling catheters).
  - Consider pregnancy test (if applicable) and screening for diabetes.
  - Imaging (renal ultrasound or CT) if recurrent, complicated, or if you fail to improve (to look for stones, obstruction, anatomic abnormality).
  - Consider referral to urology for recurrent episodes or if imaging suggests abnormality.
  - If infections meet criteria (commonly ≥2 in 6 months or ≥3 in 12 months), options include postcoital single-dose or continuous low‑dose prophylactic antibiotics (e.g., nitrofurantoin or trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole) guided by culture history.

Prevention tips
- Empty bladder after intercourse, avoid spermicides, maintain hydration, and consider behavioral measures. Discuss pros/cons of cranberry products and prophylaxis with your provider.

When to seek emergency care
- Worsening fever, persistent vomiting, lightheadedness, fainting, worsening flank pain, decreasing urine output, or signs of sepsis (very low BP, rapid heart rate) — go to the ER.

If you’d like, tell me if you’re pregnant, allergic to antibiotics, or have had recent antibiotic resistance on cultures, and I can give more specific antibiotic recommendations.

question:
I took my 4-month-old infant to the doctor after experiencing sudden nosebleeds that occurred without any apparent trauma. Alongside this, I noticed he had been developing multiple bruises, each about 1 cm in diameter, on his hands and feet over the past month. Additionally, tiny red spots appeared on his arms and legs, again without any injury.

At the doctor's office, his vital signs were taken. His heart rate was measured at 190 beats per minute, respiratory rate at 40 breaths per minute, blood pressure at 99 over 42 mm Hg, and his temperature was 36.6 °C (97.9 °F). During the physical examination, the doctor noted that his skin appeared pale, and there were petechiae on the soft palate and both upper and lower extremities, as well as bruising on the backs of his hands and feet.

He had no prior history of bleeding issues, nor was there any relevant family history. Various blood tests were conducted, including a complete blood count and coagulation tests. The results showed several abnormalities, including signs of hypochromia and large platelets. The doctor discussed the findings and the increased bleeding time, but the specific cause of his condition was not determined during the visit.
options: A. Von Willebrand disease B. Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia C. Aspirin D. Bernard-Soulier disease E. Scurvy
default:
Summary impression
- The combination of easy mucocutaneous bleeding (nosebleeds, oral petechiae), multiple petechiae/bruises, pallor, an increased bleeding time and “large platelets” on the labs points to a platelet problem (either low platelet number or abnormal platelet function), not a primary clotting-factor disorder. The hypochromia indicates concomitant anemia. The very fast heart rate could reflect anemia, distress or pain.

Most important possible causes (differential; not a diagnosis)
- Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP): common in infants and young children; acute onset mucocutaneous bleeding, platelet count low and often large/young platelets on smear.  
- Congenital macrothrombocytopenias (e.g., Bernard–Soulier syndrome, MYH9-related disorders such as May–Hegglin): cause large platelets, prolonged bleeding time and mucosal bleeding; present in infancy/early childhood.  
- Platelet function disorders (e.g., Glanzmann thrombasthenia or severe von Willebrand disease): cause mucosal bleeding and prolonged bleeding time; platelet count may be normal (vWD) or abnormal function.  
- Bone-marrow disorders including leukemia: can present with pallor, bruising and petechiae; peripheral smear and differential may show blasts.  
- Less likely etiologies: neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia (usually presents earlier), nutritional causes won’t explain isolated bleeding signs.

What to do next (urgent steps)
1. Urgent referral to a pediatric hematologist if not already arranged.  
2. Key tests to obtain (if not already done):  
   - CBC with platelet count, mean platelet volume (MPV) and peripheral blood smear (look for platelet size, platelet clumping, blasts, Döhle-like bodies).  
   - Coagulation panel: PT, aPTT, fibrinogen, D-dimer.  
   - Platelet function testing (ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation for Bernard–Soulier; aggregation studies/platelet function analyzer).  
   - von Willebrand studies (vWF antigen and activity/Ristocetin cofactor).  
   - Reticulocyte count, iron studies (to evaluate the hypochromic anemia).  
   - Consider bone-marrow examination if peripheral smear/counts suggest leukemia or marrow failure.  
   - If congenital disorder suspected, genetic testing (after hematology consult).

Immediate practical/ safety measures
- If significant bleeding occurs (heavy nosebleed that won’t stop, large expanding bruises, persistent bleeding from mucosa, difficulty breathing, lethargy or poor feeding), go to the emergency department immediately.  
- Avoid aspirin/NSAIDs and intramuscular injections. Apply firm pressure to bleeding sites; for nosebleeds pinch the soft part of the nose and keep the infant calm/upright.  
- Bring all lab results and photos of the bruises to the hematology visit.

Treatment considerations (to be decided by hematology)
- If severe bleeding or very low platelets: platelet transfusion, IVIG or corticosteroids may be used (common first-line for ITP).  
- For congenital platelet function disorders, management is specialist-directed and may include platelet transfusions for severe bleeds and preventive measures.

If you want, send me the CBC values (platelet count, hemoglobin, MCV/MPV, WBCs) and any smear description or labs already done. I can help interpret them and suggest the next priority test.

question:
I was brought to the emergency department when I was three months old due to two days of increasing difficulty breathing and a dry cough. Five weeks prior, I had been diagnosed with diffuse hemangiomas affecting my intrathoracic cavity and started treatment with prednisolone. Upon arrival, I appeared uncomfortable and was in moderate respiratory distress. My temperature was recorded at 38°C (100.4°F), my pulse was 150 beats per minute, and my breathing rate was 50 breaths per minute, with a blood pressure of 88/50 mm Hg. 

The medical staff noted that my oxygen saturation was at 87% while I was on room air. During the oral examination, they observed a white plaque on my tongue that bled when scraped. A chest examination revealed subcostal and intercostal retractions, along with scattered fine crackles and rhonchi throughout both lung fields. The doctors conducted laboratory studies, which showed an elevated leukocyte count and increased serum beta-D-glucan concentration. A chest X-ray indicated symmetrical, diffuse interstitial infiltrates. The medical team planned to identify the most appropriate method to confirm my diagnosis.
options: A. Bronchoalveolar lavage B. Urine antigen test C. DNA test for CFTR mutation D. CT scan of the chest E. Tuberculin skin test F. Spirometry
default: Most likely diagnosis: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. The best way to confirm it is to obtain respiratory secretions (bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is preferred in infants) and demonstrate the organism by direct staining (Gomori methenamine silver or immunofluorescent stain) and/or PCR on the BAL specimen. BAL has higher sensitivity than induced sputum in young infants.

question:
I am a 19-year-old man who recently experienced an episode that led me to the emergency department. While I was helping my girlfriend move furniture into her apartment, I briefly lost consciousness. I was unresponsive for about a minute, but I regained consciousness quickly and was not confused afterwards. Prior to this incident, I did not experience any chest pain, palpitations, or difficulty breathing.

I have had episodes of dizziness during exercise at the gym, but I hadn’t paid much attention to them until now. When I was evaluated in the emergency department, my blood pressure measured 125/75 mm Hg while I was lying down and 120/70 mm Hg while standing. My pulse rate was 70 beats per minute when supine and increased to 75 beats per minute while standing.

During the examination, the physician noted a grade 3/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and another systolic murmur at the apex. Interestingly, both murmurs disappeared when my legs were elevated. The medical team is now considering what might be causing these symptoms.
