options: A. Prolonged QT interval B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy C. Bicuspid aortic valve D. Mitral valve prolapse E. Orthostatic syncope F. Vasovagal syncope G. Carotid sinus syndrome H. Mitral valve stenosis
default:
The pattern is most suggestive of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) with dynamic left‑ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction and secondary mitral regurgitation.

Why:
- You are a young person with exertional dizziness/syncope — classic red flag for HOCM. Exertional syncope in this age group is concerning for obstruction or malignant arrhythmia.
- The systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border fits an LVOT (HOCM) murmur; an apical systolic murmur fits mitral regurgitation from systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve that commonly accompanies HOCM.
- Both murmurs disappearing with leg elevation is key: leg raise increases venous return/preload, enlarges LV cavity and reduces the dynamic obstruction, so the murmur intensity falls. The opposite maneuvers (standing or Valsalva), which reduce preload, typically make the HOCM murmur louder.

What to do next:
- Urgent transthoracic echocardiogram to confirm asymmetric septal hypertrophy, dynamic LVOT gradient, and SAM/MR.
- 12‑lead ECG and cardiology referral. Consider ambulatory rhythm monitoring if arrhythmia suspected.
- If HOCM is confirmed: family screening/genetic counseling, avoid competitive/strenuous sports until cleared, and medical therapy (beta‑blocker or nondihydropyridine calcium‑channel blocker) or further interventions depending on severity and risk (including ICD if high risk of sudden cardiac death).

While other causes of syncope (vasovagal, arrhythmia, orthostatic) exist, the exam finding and exertional presentation point toward HOCM and warrant prompt cardiology evaluation and echo.

question:
I am a 45-year-old man who has been experiencing moderate-to-severe pelvic pain for the past two years. This pain is accompanied by irritative voiding symptoms, including increased frequency of urination and discomfort during urination, known as dysuria. Occasionally, I have noticed blood in my semen, which is often accompanied by painful ejaculation. 

Throughout this period, I have sought help from several healthcare practitioners. Each has prescribed antimicrobial therapy, including ciprofloxacin, but unfortunately, I have not experienced any improvement. This ongoing situation has led to emotional distress and difficulties with sleep. 

During my recent physical examination, the findings were mostly unremarkable, though my prostate was mildly tender. There were no indications of masses or nodules, and I did not have any testicular masses, hernias, or hemorrhoids. 

In addition to the pelvic issues, I have also been dealing with recurrent abdominal pain, alternating between constipation and diarrhea, and I often feel fatigued. Despite these symptoms, all my test results have been within the normal range. I remain hopeful that my healthcare team can help identify the underlying cause of my symptoms.
options: A. Benign prostatic hyperplasia B. Chronic, non-bacterial prostatitis C. Acute prostatitis by Chlamydia trachomatis D. Chronic prostatitis by resistant Escherichia coli E. Interstitial cystitis
default:
Thank you — this is a helpful, clear history. Based on what you’ve described (≥3 months of pelvic pain, irritative voiding, painful ejaculation, occasional hematospermia, mild prostate tenderness, no response to multiple antibiotic courses), the most likely diagnosis is chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CP/CPPS; NIH category III — most often nonbacterial). Other common contributors that often overlap are pelvic-floor muscle dysfunction, irritable bowel syndrome/central sensitization, and psychosocial stress/sleep disturbance.

What that means
- “Nonbacterial” prostatitis/CPPS is common, often does not respond to antibiotics, and is a diagnosis of exclusion when cultures and targeted testing are negative.  
- Symptoms are real and can be persistent, but they are usually not caused by prostate cancer or an urgent surgical problem when exams and tests are otherwise unremarkable.

Recommended next steps (diagnosis)
1. Avoid further empiric antibiotics unless you have positive cultures or a clear new infectious exposure. Repeated fluoroquinolone courses are not advised without culture guidance.  
2. Obtain targeted testing if not already done:
   - Urine dip/urinalysis and urine culture.  
   - Pre- and post-prostatic-massage urine and/or expressed prostatic secretion (EPS) or semen culture / microscope (to look for inflammation and bacteria; Meares–Stamey or two-glass variation).  
   - NAAT (PCR) testing for chlamydia/gonorrhea (first-void urine) if not already done.  
   - Basic bloods if not recently done (CBC, CRP) and consider PSA only if clinically indicated or for baseline discussion with urology.  
3. Imaging or scopes only if indicated by persistent hematospermia, hematuria, focal findings, or failure of conservative therapy:
   - Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) or pelvic MRI for seminal vesicles/prostate if persistent hematospermia or concern for structural lesion.  
   - Cystoscopy if frank hematuria, visible bleeding, or significant voiding abnormalities.

Treatment approach (multimodal)
Because CP/CPPS is typically multifactorial, the best outcomes come from a combined strategy:

A. Conservative/self-care
- Voiding habits: timed voiding, avoid straining, limit bladder irritants (caffeine, alcohol, spicy foods).  
- Warm baths / sitz baths, gentle perineal massage, avoiding prolonged sitting.  
- Pelvic-floor relaxation techniques and breathing exercises.  
- Good sleep hygiene; treat insomnia (CBT-I or short-term sleep strategies).

B. Physical therapy
- Referral to a pelvic-floor physical therapist experienced with male pelvic pain (biofeedback, trigger-point release, relaxation) — high yield for many men.

C. Medications (individualized)
- Alpha-blocker (tamsulosin or similar) can help urinary frequency/urgency and voiding symptoms; consider trial ~4–8 weeks.  
- Analgesics/NSAIDs for pain control as needed.  
- Neuropathic pain agents if pain is more neuropathic or central-sensitization features: low-dose tricyclic (e.g., nortriptyline or amitriptyline), gabapentin/pregabalin, or an SNRI (duloxetine) — discuss side effects with your clinician.  
- 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors have limited evidence and are not routine.  
- Avoid further long empirical antibiotic courses unless cultures support infection.

D. Procedures / specialist options (if refractory)
- Trigger-point injections, Botox to pelvic floor (in selected centers), or referral to a chronic pain clinic or urology for advanced options.  
- Multidisciplinary care: urology + pelvic-floor PT + pain medicine + mental health (CBT for pain) often works best.

E. Addressing hematospermia
- If semen/blood-in-semen continues, get semen analysis/culture and TRUS if persistent >3 months or if bleeding increases. Urology referral is appropriate for persistent hematospermia.

Psychosocial care
- Because chronic pain affects mood and sleep, consider psychological support (CBT, mindfulness-based therapy) and assessment/treatment for anxiety or depression. This can improve pain coping and sleep.

When to seek urgent care
- Fever, inability to urinate (acute urinary retention), rapidly worsening pain, significant testicular swelling/mass, unexplained weight loss, or gross hematuria — these need prompt evaluation.

How to proceed now
1. Stop empiric antibiotics unless you have a positive culture.  
2. Ask your clinician for pelvic-muscle evaluation and referral to a pelvic-floor physical therapist.  
3. Discuss a trial of an alpha-blocker plus a neuropathic agent or low-dose TCA to help pain and sleep.  
4. Get a urology referral (especially if hematospermia persists, symptoms worsen, or conservative measures fail after 6–12 weeks).  
5. Consider concurrent referral to a pain clinic or mental health for CBT/sleep therapy.

If you like, I can:
- Draft a concise summary you can bring to your next clinic visit.  
- Suggest specific questions to ask your urologist or pelvic-floor therapist.  
- Help find patient resources or guides for pelvic-floor physiotherapy and CBT for chronic pelvic pain.

You’re doing the right thing seeking a multidisciplinary approach — CP/CPPS is chronic but often manageable with the strategies above.

question:
I am a 59-year-old woman who experienced a sudden onset of severe pain around my left eye and blurred vision in that same eye. This pain began shortly after I entered a theater to watch a movie. As the discomfort intensified, I developed a headache and vomited twice while on my way to the hospital.

Two weeks prior, I had an episode of acute sinusitis that resolved on its own. I have a history of atrial fibrillation and hypertension, for which I take metoprolol and warfarin. Upon arriving at the emergency department, my temperature was recorded at 37.1°C (98.8°F), my pulse was 101 beats per minute, and my blood pressure was 140/80 mm Hg.

In the examination, my visual acuity in the left eye was limited to counting fingers at a distance of three feet, while my right eye maintained a clear vision of 20/20. The left eye showed signs of conjunctival injection and an edematous cornea. Additionally, my left pupil was mid-dilated and irregular, showing no reaction to light. Despite normal extraocular movements, a fundoscopic examination could not provide clear results due to the severe corneal edema.
options: A. Central retinal artery occlusion B. Open-angle glaucoma C. Retrobulbar neuritis D. Acute iridocyclitis E. Orbital cellulitis F. Angle-closure glaucoma
default:
Most likely diagnosis: acute primary angle‑closure (acute closed‑angle) glaucoma of the left eye.

Why: the classic picture is sudden severe unilateral eye pain, blurred vision, headache, nausea/vomiting, a mid‑dilated nonreactive pupil, conjunctival injection and corneal edema with inability to see the fundus — often precipitated by pupillary dilation (dark movie theater).

Immediate actions (urgent ophthalmology care required):
- Confirm with tonometry (expect markedly elevated IOP, often >40 mmHg) and gonioscopy.
- Medical therapy to rapidly lower IOP while arranging definitive treatment:
  - IV or oral acetazolamide (e.g., 500 mg IV once or 500 mg PO if IV not available) unless contraindicated.
  - Topical IOP‑lowering drops: topical beta‑blocker (timolol 0.5%), apraclonidine if available. Be aware systemic beta‑blockade can interact with metoprolol—use under supervision.
  - Topical pilocarpine (1–2%) given after initial IOP lowering (often repeated q5–15 min for a few doses) to induce miosis and open the angle.
  - If very high IOP or not responsive, IV mannitol may be used.
  - Analgesia and antiemetics as needed.
- Definitive treatment: urgent peripheral iridotomy (laser YAG iridotomy) to relieve pupillary block; often performed same day. Prophylactic iridotomy of the fellow eye is commonly recommended.
- Avoid mydriatics/anticholinergics.

Special considerations in your case:
- Inform ophthalmology about warfarin and atrial fibrillation. Laser iridotomy is usually possible without stopping anticoagulation, but the team will decide case‑by‑case.
- Because you’re on metoprolol, topical beta‑blockers can increase bradycardia risk; the ophthalmologist will weigh risks and may choose alternatives.

This is an ocular emergency — if this is still ongoing or recurs, seek immediate ophthalmology/ER care.

question:
I brought my 9-month-old infant to the physician because she had developed a generalized nonpruritic rash that lasted for two days. The rash initially appeared on her trunk and then spread to her extremities. Prior to this, five days ago, she had a high fever of 40.5°C (104.9°F) and experienced a 1-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which prompted a visit to the emergency department. 

She was born at term and has not had any serious illnesses in the past. Her immunizations are up-to-date, and the only medication she is currently taking is acetaminophen for her fever. At the physician's office, her temperature was 37.2°C (99.0°F) and her pulse was recorded at 120 beats per minute. During the examination, the doctor noted a maculopapular rash that blanched under pressure and also observed posterior auricular lymphadenopathy. 

The physician discussed the situation with me and indicated that they would consider various diagnoses based on her symptoms and clinical presentation.
options: A. Kawasaki disease B. Drug allergy C. Scarlet fever D. Impetigo E. Roseola infantum F. Measles G. Fifth disease H. Rubella
default:
Most likely diagnosis: roseola infantum (exanthem subitum) caused by human herpesvirus‑6/7.

Why: classic age (6–18 months), very high fever for several days with a febrile seizure, then abrupt defervescence followed by a blanching, nonpruritic maculopapular rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities. Although posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is more classically described with rubella, rubella is less likely here because its rash usually begins on the face, systemic illness is milder, and it doesn’t typically cause very high fevers with febrile seizures.

Management: supportive care (antipyretics, fluids) and reassurance. Febrile seizures from roseola are usually benign; observe for recurrence and seek urgent care for prolonged seizures, focal deficits, or poor responsiveness. No specific antiviral therapy is indicated; testing is rarely necessary unless the diagnosis is unclear or the infant is immunocompromised.

question:
Three days after my delivery, my newborn daughter, who weighed 1100 grams (2 pounds 7 ounces) and was born at 31 weeks' gestation, experienced a tonic seizure lasting 25 seconds. I noticed that she had become increasingly lethargic over the past 18 hours. During the antenatal period, I had complications due to chorioamnionitis. Her Apgar scores were recorded as 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes after birth, respectively, indicating she appeared ill at that time. 

At the last examination, her pulse was 123 beats per minute, and her respirations were 50 breaths per minute and irregular. Her blood pressure measured 60/30 mm Hg. The physician noted a tense anterior fontanelle, and her pupils were equal but reacted sluggishly to light. There were also slow, conjugate back-and-forth movements of her eyes, and I observed decreased muscle tone in all her extremities. Fortunately, her lungs were clear when examined. Given these concerning signs and symptoms, I was anxious about her condition and awaited further assessment and diagnosis.
options: A. Galactosemia B. Spinal muscular atrophy C. Phenylketonuria D. Congenital hydrocephalus E. Intraventricular hemorrhage
default:
Most likely diagnoses
- Germinal‑matrix/intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) — very common in very‑low‑birthweight preterm infants in the first 72 hours and fits the tense fontanelle, new seizure, lethargy and hypotonia.
- Neonatal meningitis/sepsis — maternal chorioamnionitis increases risk; meningitis can also cause bulging fontanelle, seizures and lethargy.
- Less likely/other contributors: metabolic causes (hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, electrolyte abnormalities) or evolving hypoxic‑ischemic encephalopathy.

Immediate management (urgent)
1. ABCs — support airway and breathing; give supplemental oxygen and ventilatory support as needed.  
2. Check bedside glucose immediately and treat hypoglycaemia (IV dextrose bolus) if present.  
3. Stop ongoing seizures: give IV benzodiazepine (eg, lorazepam or midazolam) then phenobarbital per neonatal dosing if seizures persist.  
4. Circulation: treat hypotension (IV fluid bolus, then inotropes if needed) and monitor cardiorespiratory status.  
5. Obtain urgent labs: bedside glucose, electrolytes/Ca/Mg, blood gas, CBC, blood culture, CRP, coagulation studies.  
6. Start empiric antibiotics promptly after blood cultures if sepsis/meningitis suspected (typical neonatal regimen discussed with neonatology — often ampicillin plus an agent active against gram‑negatives; for meningitis many centers use ampicillin + cefotaxime).  
7. Neuroimaging urgently: bedside cranial ultrasound (first line in preterm infants) to look for IVH/hydrocephalus. If ultrasound equivocal or more detail needed, CT or MRI can follow.  
8. Do NOT perform lumbar puncture until neuroimaging excludes mass effect/markedly increased intracranial pressure and the baby is hemodynamically stable.  
9. Consult neonatology immediately; involve pediatric neurology and neurosurgery if imaging shows large IVH/hydrocephalus or if seizures are difficult to control.

Brief prognosis note
- Outcome depends on cause and severity (grade of IVH, presence of meningitis, response to therapy). Very‑low‑birthweight preterms with high‑grade IVH or meningitis have increased risk of mortality and long‑term neurodevelopmental impairment.

If you want, I can list the expected imaging findings for IVH vs meningitis and typical empiric antibiotic regimens used in neonates.

question:
I am a 61-year-old man with no significant health issues prior to this experience. For the past three months, I have been dealing with intermittent fever, which has been accompanied by a notable sense of easy fatiguability. During this time, I have also lost about 4.4 kilograms (9.7 pounds) in weight without any deliberate effort to do so.

Recently, I went to see my physician to discuss these concerning symptoms. During the examination, the doctor noted conjunctival pallor, which caught their attention. Additionally, they palpated my spleen and found it to be enlarged, extending 5 centimeters below my left costal margin. 

As part of the evaluation, laboratory studies were conducted. The results indicated a leukocyte count of 75,300 per cubic millimeter, with an increase in basophils and a platelet count of 455,000 per cubic millimeter. There was also a decreased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score. A peripheral blood smear showed an increased number of promyelocytes, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes.

These findings have led my physician to consider a diagnosis, and I am awaiting further discussions on the next steps for my health.
options: A. Leukemoid reaction B. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia C. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia D. Polycythemia vera E. Essential thrombocythemia F. Chronic myeloid leukemia G. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
default:
The constellation of findings you describe — weeks to months of fatigue, weight loss, fever, marked leukocytosis with a left shift (many promyelocytes/myelocytes/metamyelocytes), basophilia, splenomegaly and a low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score — is most consistent with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), most likely in the chronic phase.

Why CML fits
- Very high WBC with immature granulocyte forms and prominent basophilia is typical of CML.  
- Splenomegaly and constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, fatigue) are common.  
- A low LAP score helps distinguish CML from a leukemoid reaction (where LAP is usually high).

Recommended next steps (discuss with your physician/hematologist urgently)
1. Confirm the diagnosis:
   - Quantitative PCR for BCR-ABL1 (Philadelphia chromosome; t(9;22)) on peripheral blood — this is the key diagnostic test.  
   - Bone marrow biopsy and cytogenetics/FISH if needed to document the abnormality and assess marrow morphology and blast percentage.
2. Baseline labs and supportive tests:
   - CBC with differential, CMP, uric acid, LDH, coagulation studies.  
   - Infectious workup if fever source unclear.
3. Initial management while workup is pending or if symptomatic:
   - Referral to a hematologist/oncologist promptly.  
   - If WBC is very high or you have symptoms of hyperviscosity, short-term cytoreduction (hydroxyurea) may be used; leukapheresis is rarely required unless severe symptoms. Allopurinol may be given to reduce risk of tumor lysis.  
4. Long-term treatment and monitoring (if diagnosis confirmed):
   - First-line therapy is a BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) such as imatinib, dasatinib, or nilotinib. These have transformed prognosis in CML.  
   - Monitoring with quantitative BCR-ABL PCR at regular intervals (e.g., 3, 6, 12 months) and periodic CBCs and clinical exams to assess response.
5. Urgent signs that need immediate attention: rapidly worsening shortness of breath, severe bleeding, severe bone pain, confusion, or very high fevers.

Prognosis
- If confirmed and treated in the chronic phase with TKIs, many patients achieve durable responses and long-term survival is markedly improved compared with historical outcomes.

Action for you now
- Request an urgent hematology consultation and ask that BCR-ABL PCR and bone marrow studies be arranged promptly. If you develop worsening symptoms (breathlessness, bleeding, neurologic symptoms, very high fevers), go to the emergency department.

If you want, I can help you draft questions to bring to your hematology appointment or summarize these points for your doctor.

question:
I am a 66-year-old man and was brought to the emergency department because I experienced weakness in my left leg for the past hour. This weakness made it impossible for me to get out of bed that morning. I noticed that my pants were soaked with urine. I have a medical history that includes hypertension and coronary artery disease. My current medications are enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and simvastatin.

Upon arrival at the hospital, my vital signs were taken. My temperature was 37°C, my pulse was 98 beats per minute, and my blood pressure was measured at 160/90 mm Hg. During the examination, the medical team noted that my pupils were equal and reactive to light. They assessed my muscle strength and found that it was 2 out of 5 in my left lower extremity. I also had a diminished plantar reflex with an extensor response on the left side. Sensation in my left leg was decreased.

When they evaluated my mental status, I was oriented to time, place, and person, but I presented with a flat affect. I was asked to count backwards from 20 but stopped after reaching 17. Additionally, when asked to name 10 words that begin with the letter "d," I was only able to name two. A fundoscopy examination showed no abnormalities.
options: A. Normal pressure hydrocephalus B. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion C. Left middle cerebral artery occlusion D. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion E. Right middle cerebral artery occlusion F. Right anterior cerebral artery occlusion G. Right posterior cerebral artery occlusion H. Left anterior cerebral artery occlusion I. Temporal lobe encephalitis J. Hypertensive encephalopathy K. Left posterior cerebral artery occlusion
default:
Most likely diagnosis: acute ischemic stroke of the right anterior cerebral artery (ACA) territory affecting the medial frontal lobe/paracentral lobule.

Why: an acute, contralateral (left) lower‑extremity weakness with upper‑motor‑neuron signs (extensor plantar response), decreased left leg sensation, and urinary incontinence localizes to the medial frontal/paracentral motor cortex supplied by the ACA. The flat affect, abulia/slowed mental set (stopping counting) and poor phonemic fluency are frontal‑executive signs consistent with medial frontal involvement. The sudden onset and vascular risk factors further support an acute infarct.

Immediate next steps (urgent):
- Emergent noncontrast head CT (to exclude hemorrhage) and CT angiography or MRI to define the infarct and vessel occlusion.
- If ischemic stroke and within the thrombolysis window and no contraindications, consider IV tPA; consider endovascular therapy if a large‑vessel occlusion is identified and patient is eligible.
- Manage blood pressure per stroke protocol, withhold antiplatelet before tPA if giving thrombolysis.
- Stroke workup for etiology (ECG/telemetry, carotid imaging, echocardiogram) and start secondary prevention once acute treatment decisions are made.

Discuss these steps with the treating team immediately.

question: I was brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after experiencing a seizure. My wife informed the medical staff that I had been having recurrent headaches and had become increasingly irritable over the past three months. During the physical examination, the doctors noted that I had a spastic paresis in my right lower extremity. They also observed that the Babinski sign was present on my right side. Following this assessment, an MRI of my brain was conducted to gather further information regarding my condition.
options: A. Pituitary adenoma B. Schwannoma C. Metastatic brain tumor D. Ependymoma E. Oligodendroglioma F. Meningioma G. Glioblastoma multiforme
default:
Most likely you have a left parasagittal (falx) meningioma compressing the paracentral lobule/medial frontal motor cortex.

Why:
- New-onset seizures, progressive headaches and personality/irritability changes over months are typical for a slowly growing intracranial tumor.
- A right-sided spastic paresis with a right Babinski indicates an upper motor neuron lesion in the left medial frontal/paracentral lobule (the cortical representation of the lower limb).
- Parasagittal meningiomas arise from the dura along the falx over that region and classically produce contralateral lower‑limb weakness, seizures and frontal behavioral changes.

Expected MRI findings:
- Extra‑axial, dural‑based mass along the left falx/parasagittal region
- Homogeneous enhancement with contrast and often a “dural tail”
- Mass effect on adjacent medial frontal cortex with surrounding vasogenic edema

Next steps/management (typical):
- Neurosurgical evaluation for resection (Simpson grade dependent), with antiepileptic control and steroids as needed for edema
- Pathology after resection confirms grade; radiotherapy may be used if subtotal resection or higher‑grade lesion

Differentials include parasagittal metastasis or a cortical glioma, but imaging (dural attachment/dural tail, extra‑axial appearance) and the clinical picture favor meningioma.

question:
I am a 52-year-old woman who went to the urgent care center after experiencing several hours of worsening abdominal discomfort that radiated to my back. Along with the abdominal pain, I felt a general malaise, had chills, and experienced nausea and vomiting. My social history includes a history of alcoholism, which may be relevant to my condition.

During the visit, the medical staff noted that I had a fever, with my temperature recorded at 39.5°C (103.1℉). Upon examination, I was found to be diffusely tender in my abdomen. My blood pressure was measured at 126/74 mm Hg, my heart rate was 74 beats per minute, and my respiratory rate was 14 breaths per minute. 

The healthcare team conducted some tests, which showed an elevated white blood cell count and abnormal levels of bilirubin and amylase. Based on my symptoms and the examination findings, the medical staff considered potential diagnoses related to my condition.
options: A. Cholelithiasis B. Acute cholecystitis C. Gallstone pancreatitis D. Choledocholithiasis E. Ascending cholangitis
default:
Your presentation (sudden severe abdominal pain radiating to the back, nausea/vomiting, history of alcoholism, fever, leukocytosis, elevated amylase and abnormal bilirubin) is most consistent with acute pancreatitis, and the alcohol history makes alcoholic pancreatitis a leading cause. The abnormal bilirubin and fever raise concern for a biliary cause or superimposed biliary infection (ascending cholangitis) or biliary obstruction from a gallstone.

Key considerations (differential)
- Acute pancreatitis (most likely): epigastric/back radiation, elevated amylase/lipase, systemic inflammatory response.
- Gallstone (biliary) pancreatitis: can produce elevated bilirubin and deranged LFTs if a stone is obstructing the common bile duct.
- Acute cholangitis: fever + jaundice + RUQ pain (Charcot triad); would require urgent biliary decompression if present.
- Acute cholecystitis or other intra‑abdominal infection/inflammation (less classic given back-radiation and amylase elevation).

Immediate next steps (what clinicians should do)
- Admit for observation and management (this presentation warrants hospital care).
- Confirm diagnosis with serum lipase (more specific than amylase) and full labs: LFTs (including ALT), BMP, CBC, coagulation studies, and blood cultures if infection suspected.
- Imaging: RUQ ultrasound to look for gallstones and bile duct dilation; contrast-enhanced CT abdomen if diagnosis unclear or to assess severity/complications.
- Initial treatment: NPO, aggressive IV fluids (crystalloid, e.g., lactated Ringer’s), adequate analgesia (opioids as needed), and antiemetics.
- If features of ascending cholangitis (fever, jaundice, hypotension, confusion) or persistent biliary obstruction: urgent ERCP for biliary decompression.
- Antibiotics are not routinely given for uncomplicated pancreatitis; give antibiotics if there is suspected infected necrosis or proven cholangitis/sepsis.

Monitoring and follow-up
- Monitor vitals, urine output, labs, and for complications (organ failure, necrosis, pseudocyst, ARDS).
- Assess alcohol use and arrange counseling/support once stabilized.

If you haven’t already been admitted or evaluated with lipase/US/CT, go to the emergency department now for urgent hospital evaluation and treatment.

question:
I am a 48-year-old woman who visited an urgent care clinic due to several concerning symptoms. For the past three days, I have been experiencing bloody diarrhea, mid-abdominal discomfort, and cramping. Alongside these issues, I have also felt nausea, had episodes of vomiting, and developed a mild fever. 

I recalled that nearly three days prior, I had eaten raw oysters at a local seafood restaurant. I did not identify any other potential sources of infection. During my visit, my temperature was recorded at 37.5°C (99.6°F), with a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, a pulse of 67 beats per minute, and blood pressure measuring 102/68 mm Hg. 

The physical examination conducted at the clinic did not reveal any additional findings. Based on my symptoms and recent dietary choices, I was informed that a diagnosis would be considered.
options: A. Rotavirus infection B. C. difficile colitis C. Bacillus cereus infection D. Norovirus infection E. Vibrio parahaemolyticus infection
default:
Most likely diagnosis: Vibrio gastroenteritis (most commonly Vibrio parahaemolyticus) from eating raw oysters.

Why: raw oysters are a classic source of Vibrio species. The typical presentation is acute onset (within 1–3 days) of abdominal cramps, nausea/vomiting, fever and watery to sometimes bloody diarrhea. Your timing and symptoms fit this pattern.

What’s usually done:
- Diagnostic testing: stool culture or PCR targeted for Vibrio (labs use selective media such as TCBS agar) — ask your clinician to request Vibrio testing specifically.
- Usual course: infection is often self-limited over several days to a week in healthy people.
- Supportive care: oral rehydration / fluids, antiemetics if needed. Avoid antimotility agents (e.g., loperamide) if you have fever or bloody diarrhea.
- Antibiotics: not routinely required for mild disease. They are recommended for severe illness, high fever, persistent bloody diarrhea, signs of sepsis, or for patients at high risk (liver disease, immunosuppression). Typical agents used by clinicians include doxycycline or a fluoroquinolone/azithromycin depending on severity and local susceptibility — your treating clinician will decide.

When to seek urgent care or ED:
- Worsening fever, severe abdominal pain, signs of dehydration (dizziness, little/no urine), persistent vomiting, rapid heart rate or low blood pressure, or any signs of systemic infection. Also seek care urgently if you have liver disease, diabetes, or any immunosuppression.

If you’d like, tell me whether you have any chronic liver disease or are taking immunosuppressive medicines and I can give more specific advice.

question:
I am a 29-year-old man who visited my physician due to a 3-month history of persistent fatigue and unintentional weight loss. During this time, I also noticed multiple painless swellings on my neck and in my axilla. I observed that these swellings would become painful after I consumed alcohol. 

During my physical examination, the doctor identified nontender lymphadenopathy in both my cervical and axillary regions. To better understand my condition, a lymph node biopsy was performed. The results of the biopsy revealed the presence of giant binucleate cells.

Overall, I am seeking clarity on my symptoms and the potential diagnosis resulting from these findings.
options: A. Hodgkin lymphoma B. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma C. Mycobacterial infection D. Adult T-cell lymphoma E. Acute lymphocytic leukemia F. Acute retroviral syndrome
default:
The findings you describe are most consistent with Hodgkin lymphoma.

Why this fits
- Painless, progressive cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy in a young adult with systemic "B symptoms" (weight loss, fatigue) is typical.
- Lymph node biopsy showing giant binucleate cells is the hallmark: Reed–Sternberg cells (often described as “owl’s‑eye” cells).
- Alcohol-induced pain in previously painless nodes is a classic (though not universal) feature of Hodgkin lymphoma.

Key points about Hodgkin lymphoma
- Reed–Sternberg cells are usually of B‑cell origin and characteristically express CD15 and CD30.
- Subtypes exist (e.g., nodular sclerosis is common in young adults). Prognosis and treatment depend on subtype and stage.
- It is generally highly treatable; early‑stage disease has a very good long‑term survival rate.

Recommended next steps
1. Urgent referral to a hematologist/oncologist.  
2. Staging workup: PET‑CT (or CT chest/abdomen/pelvis with PET), CBC, ESR/CRP, LDH, liver/renal function, and bone marrow biopsy if indicated.  
3. Tumor immunophenotyping to confirm Reed–Sternberg markers (CD15, CD30) and to classify the subtype.  
4. Discussion about treatment options (commonly chemotherapy ± radiotherapy; ABVD regimen is frequently used) and fertility preservation if treatment is planned.

If you’d like, I can help you prepare questions for your oncologist or explain staging and typical treatment regimens in more detail.

question:
I am a 51-year-old man with a history of alcohol use. I recently found myself in the emergency department due to persistent vomiting. I had been vomiting forcefully next to an empty bottle of vodka. My medical history includes treatment for Lyme disease, which I have been managing with doxycycline.

While in the ER, I experienced a prolonged episode of retching that escalated to choking and coughing forcefully. I also began to feel chest pain during this time. I was unable to communicate effectively due to my condition, and I felt extremely unwell. 

The medical team assessed my vital signs, which indicated a concerning state: my temperature was 37°C (98.6°F), my respiratory rate was 15 breaths per minute, my pulse was elevated at 107 beats per minute, and my blood pressure was low at 90/68 mm Hg. During the physical examination, the doctor noted fullness at the base of my neck and a crunching, rasping sound when listening to my chest. 

I was then taken for an upright chest X-ray, which revealed free air in the mediastinum. The situation was alarming, and I was left to contemplate the possible implications of these findings.
options: A. Esophageal candidiasis B. Dieulafoy's lesion C. Pill esophagitis D. Boerhaave syndrome E. Mallory Weiss tear
default:
What happened is most consistent with an esophageal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome), which is a full‑thickness tear of the esophagus caused by violent retching or vomiting.

Why that fits
- Violent retching followed by sudden chest pain is the classic presentation.  
- “Fullness” at the base of the neck and a crunching/rasping sound with cardiac beats (Hamman’s sign) and palpable crepitus point to air tracking into the mediastinum and soft tissues.  
- Upright chest X‑ray showing free air in the mediastinum (pneumomediastinum) is a key radiographic finding consistent with an esophageal leak.  
- Your tachycardia and low blood pressure are concerning for systemic inflammation, sepsis, or mediastinitis from contamination of the mediastinum.

Why this is urgent
- Esophageal perforation allows saliva, gastric contents and bacteria to enter the mediastinum or pleural space, rapidly causing life‑threatening infection (mediastinitis, sepsis). It is a surgical emergency; delays increase morbidity and mortality.

Typical next steps (what emergency teams usually do)
- Immediate nil by mouth (NPO), high‑flow IV fluids, oxygen and close monitoring (often ICU).  
- Broad‑spectrum IV antibiotics that cover oral/upper GI flora (examples: piperacillin‑tazobactam, or a third‑generation cephalosporin plus metronidazole; choices depend on local practice/allergies).  
- Urgent surgical (thoracic) consultation.  
- Imaging to confirm and localize the leak: CT chest with IV contrast and water‑soluble oral contrast (or a contrast esophagogram with Gastrografin).  
- Management may include primary surgical repair (often best if done early, within 24 hours), endoscopic stent placement in selected cases, chest‑tube drainage if there is pleural contamination, and nutritional support (NPO with TPN or feeding tube distal to the leak) while healing occurs.

What to expect and prognosis
- Treatment and recovery depend on how quickly the diagnosis is made and treated, the size/location of the tear, and whether the mediastinum/pleura are contaminated. Early treatment substantially improves outcomes; delays lead to higher rates of sepsis, longer hospital stays, and higher mortality.

If you were discharged or not yet evaluated fully: return to the emergency department immediately or contact your care team. This condition requires prompt hospital care.

question:
I am a 7-year-old boy, and my mother brought me to the physician to discuss some issues I've been experiencing. For the past six months, I have had abdominal pain, particularly crampy sensations every morning on school days. I started at a new school seven months ago, and my mother is worried because I've missed school frequently due to this pain.

In addition to the abdominal discomfort, I have been having trouble falling asleep at night. I often ask to sleep in the same room as my parents, which seems to help me feel more secure. I have not experienced any fever, vomiting, diarrhea, or weight loss during this time.

When we were at the doctor's office, I found myself sitting very close to my mother and felt upset when she stepped out of the room to take a phone call. The doctor examined my abdomen and found no abnormalities. My mother and I are both curious about what might be causing these symptoms.
options: A. Separation anxiety disorder B. Normal behavior C. Irritable bowel syndrome D. Conduct disorder E. Acute stress disorder
default:
It sounds like you and your mom are dealing with anxiety about being away from each other, most likely separation anxiety that’s showing up as tummy aches on school mornings and trouble sleeping. A few things point to that:

- The problems started soon after you began a new school.  
- The stomach pain happens mostly on school days and there are no medical findings.  
- You want to sleep near your parents and get upset when your mom leaves.  
- This has been going on for months and is making it hard for you to go to school.

What that means
- Separation anxiety (sometimes called “school refusal” when it mostly happens for school) is common in young children and often causes real physical symptoms like stomachaches, headaches, and trouble sleeping.  
- It is not your fault, and it is treatable.

Helpful next steps
1. Talk with your pediatrician and ask for a referral to a child psychologist or therapist who treats anxiety. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) with gradual practice being apart from your parents works very well.  
2. Work with the school (teacher, counselor) so they know what’s happening and can support a plan to help you come to school more gradually if needed.  
3. Try a calm, predictable morning and bedtime routine (limited screens before bed, a short calming activity, same wakeup/bedtime).  
4. Use small steps to practice separations (short, planned separations that slowly get longer), and praise or reward successes so staying at school is reinforced. Allow a safe transitional object if that helps, but avoid letting staying home be the usual solution.  
5. Keep a short diary of when the pain happens, what seems to make it better or worse, and any stressful events — that helps the doctor and therapist.

When to seek urgent help
- If you notice severe changes in mood, thoughts about hurting yourself, big weight loss, or inability to eat/sleep, contact your doctor or emergency services right away.

If you’d like, I can write a short note you or your mom can give to the pediatrician or school counselor, or suggest a simple plan of small steps to practice separation at home.

question:
I am a 23-year-old woman who was brought to the emergency department by my boyfriend due to a persistent feeling of sadness that has lasted for four months. During this time, I have been sleeping and eating very little, and I have struggled to focus at work. I often feel empty inside and have begun hearing voices that tell me I am worthless. The first time I heard these voices was seven months ago, and they made fun of me.

I do not consume alcohol or use any illicit drugs. When I was examined, both physical and neurological assessments showed no abnormalities. However, during the mental status examination, my speech was noted to be slow and monotonous. At times, I abruptly stop talking mid-sentence and do not finish my thoughts. I also find myself occasionally looking up at the ceiling as if I am listening to someone. This experience has been distressing for me and has significantly impacted my daily life.
options: A. Schizophrenia B. Schizophreniform disorder C. Brief psychotic disorder D. Schizoaffective disorder E. Mood disorder with psychotic features F. Schizotypal personality disorder
default:
Most likely diagnosis: schizophrenia.

Why: you report auditory hallucinations (voices) beginning 7 months ago, plus slowed/monotonous speech, thought blocking, apparent responding to internal stimuli, and marked functional impairment. DSM criteria for schizophrenia require characteristic symptoms (hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms) and a duration of illness of at least 6 months; your timeline and symptom pattern fit. This is less consistent with major depressive disorder with psychotic features (those psychotic symptoms would occur only during mood episodes) or schizoaffective disorder (mood symptoms must be present for the majority of the illness; here psychosis preceded the depression and mood symptoms have not been the majority).

Immediate next steps
- Safety assessment now (suicidal ideation or plans, ability to care for yourself). If you have thoughts of harming yourself or cannot keep safe, go to the ED or call emergency services right away.
- Urgent psychiatric evaluation (possible inpatient admission if risk is high or functioning is very impaired).
- Treatment usually begins with an antipsychotic (most commonly a second‑generation antipsychotic). A psychiatrist will discuss options, benefits, and side effects.
- Baseline tests before/after antipsychotic start: pregnancy test if applicable, fasting glucose/A1c, lipids, weight/BMI, liver/renal function, and ECG as indicated.
- Longer-term care: medication follow-up, psychotherapy (CBT for psychosis), psychosocial supports, vocational rehabilitation, and family education.

If you want, I can help you prepare questions for the psychiatrist, a safety checklist, or a brief script to tell your boyfriend or a clinician about your symptoms.

question:
I am a 37-year-old man who recently went to the emergency department with my wife due to severe pain in my right arm that has lasted for three days. This pain began one morning after I woke up, having slept on my side, and since then, I have been unable to move my right arm. I generally consider myself healthy, but I have been feeling increasingly exhausted from working several night shifts each week as a waiter. 

During the day, I struggle to stay awake, especially while caring for our daughter, and I often feel like I can barely keep my eyes open. Because of the pain, I have been unable to work, which has placed additional financial strain on my family. My wife has taken on an extra shift to help cover our monthly bills.

When I arrived at the emergency department, I felt relaxed but hesitant to allow the medical team to examine me until my wife encouraged me to cooperate. The medical staff noted that my vital signs were within normal limits. Upon examination, I had very limited muscle strength in my right arm and no sensation to light touch over the entire area. However, when a pin prick test was performed, I reflexively withdrew my right arm.
options: A. Brachial neuritis B. Factitious disorder C. Somatic symptom disorder D. Malingering E. Conversion disorder F. Radial nerve palsy G. Illness anxiety disorder
default:
Short answer: this looks most like an acute brachial plexus/upper-limb peripheral nerve injury (either a compressive neuropathy from sleeping on the arm or idiopathic brachial neuritis/“Parsonage–Turner” syndrome). That explains severe pain then profound weakness and the abnormal sensation exam. The preserved withdrawal to pin-prick is a spinal reflex and doesn’t prove normal conscious sensation.

Why I think this
- Sudden severe arm pain on waking followed by inability to move the whole arm fits an acute peripheral nerve/plexus problem more than a stroke (no face or leg involvement, normal vitals, and reflex withdrawal despite lack of conscious touch).
- Sleeping on one side can cause prolonged compression of nerves, and brachial neuritis can present with severe pain followed by weakness and sensory loss.
- Different nerve fiber types carry different sensations: light touch (Aβ) can be lost while pain (Aδ/C) and the spinal withdrawal reflex remain.

What to do now
1. See neurology or an orthopaedic/sports shoulder/plexus specialist promptly (within a few days). Early evaluation guides treatment and prognosis.
2. Tests they will likely order:
   - Nerve conduction studies / electromyography (NCS/EMG) — usually done 1–3 weeks after onset to localize lesion and assess severity.
   - MRI of the brachial plexus and/or cervical spine if plexus tear, root avulsion, structural lesion, or severe deficit is suspected.
3. Immediate management:
   - Strong pain control (NSAIDs, short course opioids if needed, neuropathic agents like gabapentin if advised).
   - Immobilize/protect the limb, begin gentle range-of-motion to avoid contracture once pain allows.
   - If the team suspects brachial neuritis, a short course of corticosteroids is sometimes used (discuss risks/benefits with the treating physician).
   - Early physio/OT input for splints and motor retraining.
4. Red flags requiring immediate return to ED:
   - New breathing or swallowing difficulty, spreading numbness/weakness, facial involvement, loss of bladder/bowel control, or rapidly worsening symptoms.

About your daytime sleepiness
- Shift work and chronic sleep deprivation can cause severe daytime sleepiness and increased accident risk. You should not drive or operate heavy machinery if you “can barely keep your eyes open.”
- Consider discussing schedule changes with your employer, taking planned naps, strict sleep hygiene, and a referral to a sleep medicine specialist if sleepiness persists (to rule out sleep apnea, shift-work disorder, narcolepsy, etc.).

Prognosis
- Recovery depends on cause and severity. Compressive neuropathies often improve over weeks–months; brachial neuritis can take months to a year and sometimes leaves residual weakness. Early specialist care and rehabilitation improve outcomes.

If you want, tell me whether you’ve had recent infections, vaccinations, trauma, or other neurologic symptoms; I can help you prepare questions to ask the neurologist or suggest what to pack for the visit.

question:
I was involved in a motor vehicle accident and was brought to the emergency department. Upon arrival, I was unconscious and had been intubated in the field. My medical history was unknown to the medical staff. I presented with hypotension and tachycardia. 

My vital signs indicated a temperature of 37.2°C (99.1°F), a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. My blood pressure was recorded at 85/60 mm Hg. Medical personnel noted no signs of head trauma; I was responsive to pain stimuli, and my pupils measured 2mm and reacted to light. 

The examination of my heart revealed a regular rhythm without murmurs or rubs, and my lungs were clear upon auscultation. However, my abdomen was firm and distended, and bowel sounds were decreased. My extremities felt cool and clammy, with weak, thready pulses, but there was no peripheral edema. 

Given these findings, the medical team would need to determine the likely cause of my condition.
options: A. Neurogenic shock B. Cardiogenic shock C. Obstructive shock D. Hypovolemic shock E. Septic shock
default:
The presentation is most consistent with hypovolemic (hemorrhagic) shock from intra‑abdominal hemorrhage after blunt trauma (eg, splenic or hepatic injury, pelvic fracture).

Why: hypotension with reflex tachycardia, cool clammy skin and weak/thready pulses indicate low circulating volume. A firm, distended abdomen with decreased bowel sounds points to intra‑abdominal injury/bleeding. Pupils reactive and lungs clear argue against major traumatic brain injury or cardiopulmonary causes; lack of JVD, muffled heart sounds, or unilateral absent breath sounds makes tamponade or tension pneumothorax less likely.

Immediate actions the team would take: secure large‑bore IV/IO access, begin volume resuscitation and blood products (activate massive transfusion if needed), perform a rapid e-FAST (or diagnostic peritoneal lavage if indicated) to look for intraperitoneal free fluid, pelvic x‑ray/CT when stable, and urgent operative management (laparotomy/interventional radiology) if ongoing hemorrhage and hemodynamic instability.

question:
I am a 24-year-old woman who arrived at the emergency department with my boyfriend about two hours after I lost consciousness. I was seated getting a tattoo on my right upper flank when I suddenly became sweaty and pale before passing out. My boyfriend told me that I slipped to the floor and my arms and legs moved in a jerky manner for a few seconds. Fortunately, I regained consciousness within half a minute and felt alert and fully oriented right after.

I do not have a history of serious illness. I work as an event manager, and I have been experiencing more stress than usual lately due to a recent concert tour. When examined in the emergency department, I appeared well. My vital signs were stable; my temperature was 37°C, my pulse was 68 beats per minute, my respirations were 16 per minute, and my blood pressure was 120/72 mm Hg. 

The examination of my cardiopulmonary system showed no abnormalities, and the neurologic exam revealed no focal findings. An ECG indicated an incomplete right bundle branch block. I am now waiting for further evaluation to understand what might have caused my episode.
options:
A. Carotid sinus hypersensitivity B. Vasovagal syncope C. Orthostatic syncope D. Panic attack E. Tonic-clonic seizure F. Cardiac arrhythmia G. Cardiac structural abnormality
"
default:
Most likely this was a vasovagal (neurally mediated) syncope — the common “faint” from pain/stress. Points that support that diagnosis:
- Prodrome of sweating and pallor before losing consciousness (typical autonomic symptoms).
- It happened while sitting for a painful stimulus (tattoo/needle), a well-known situational trigger.
- Brief loss of consciousness with brief jerky limb movements (convulsive-looking myoclonic jerks are common in syncope).
- Rapid full recovery within 30 seconds and no post‑ictal confusion or focal deficits.
- Normal exam and stable vitals. An isolated incomplete right bundle branch block on ECG in a young person is usually benign.

What still needs to be done / when to worry
- Basic tests to exclude other causes: orthostatic vital signs, point-of-care glucose, routine bloodwork as indicated, pregnancy test if relevant. You already had an ECG; if there are any palpitations, exertional syncope, abnormal ECG, or family history of sudden death, further cardiac workup (echocardiogram, ambulatory rhythm monitor, or cardiology referral) would be needed.
- Consider neurological evaluation (EEG/neuroimaging) only if there are features suggestive of seizure: prolonged convulsion, prolonged confusion, tongue biting (especially lateral), urinary incontinence, or recurrent unexplained events.

Immediate self-care and prevention
- Stay hydrated, avoid prolonged standing, and try to recognize the prodrome (if you feel lightheaded, sit/lie down and put your head between your knees or lie flat).
- Counterpressure maneuvers (leg crossing and tensing, handgrip) can abort an impending faint.
- Avoid triggers (if needle/pain provokes you, tell providers so they can use distraction, local anesthetic, or lie you down).

When to seek urgent attention
- Any recurrent episodes, syncope during exertion, chest pain, shortness of breath, persistent neurologic deficits after an episode, or new concerning ECG findings.

If you want, I can help you prepare a short list of symptoms to tell the treating team or outline what tests you should expect while you’re being evaluated.

question:
I am a 55-year-old man who recently attended a routine check-up. During this visit, I had no complaints and my previous physical and laboratory tests had been unremarkable. My medical history includes hypercholesterolemia, which is well managed with rosuvastatin, and hypertension, which I manage with hydrochlorothiazide. Additionally, I take aspirin as part of my medication regimen.

At the appointment, I was afebrile and my vital signs were within normal limits. However, during the physical examination, my doctor noted some generalized lymphadenopathy. Following this, a blood test was conducted. The results showed an elevated white blood cell count, a normal red blood cell count, and a low hematocrit and hemoglobin level. The platelet count was within the normal range. A peripheral blood smear revealed that 92% of my cells were small normocytic lymphocytes.

Given these findings, my doctor further assessed my condition to determine the most likely diagnosis. While I am currently unaware of the specific diagnosis, I understand that my symptoms and test results are being carefully evaluated.
options: A. Acute myelogenous leukemia B. Acute lymphocytic leukemia C. Chronic myelogenous leukemia D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia E. Asymptomatic multiple myeloma
default:
Most likely diagnosis: chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (or the node‑predominant form, small lymphocytic lymphoma).

Why this fits
- Typical presentation for CLL: older adult, often asymptomatic and discovered on routine labs/physical (generalized adenopathy).  
- Blood findings match: marked lymphocytosis made up of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes on smear (CLL characteristically shows small lymphocytes and often “smudge” cells).  
- Mild anemia with normal platelets is consistent with early/mid CLL; thrombocytopenia usually appears later if marrow is heavily involved.

How it is confirmed
- Flow cytometry on peripheral blood to demonstrate a monoclonal B‑cell population with the typical immunophenotype: CD19+, CD20 (dim), CD5+, CD23+, and light‑chain restriction (kappa or lambda).  
- Additional tests for staging/prognosis: FISH for del(13q), del(11q), del(17p)/TP53, trisomy 12; beta-2 microglobulin; baseline CMP. Bone‑marrow biopsy is not always required up front if flow cytometry is diagnostic.

Next steps and management overview
- Arrange prompt hematology/oncology referral for confirmation and staging (Rai or Binet).  
- If confirmed and you are asymptomatic with early-stage disease, the standard approach is careful observation (“watchful waiting”) rather than immediate treatment.  
- Treatment is indicated for symptomatic disease, progressive cytopenias, bulky lymphadenopathy/splenomegaly, or high‑risk genetic features; modern therapies include BTK inhibitors (e.g., ibrutinib), BCL2 inhibitors (venetoclax), and anti‑CD20 antibodies (rituximab/obinutuzumab).  
- Because CLL impairs immune function, vaccination review and infection monitoring are important; discuss immunoglobulin testing if recurrent infections.

When to seek urgent care
- New fevers, rapidly enlarging nodes, night sweats/weight loss, marked bleeding, or rapidly dropping blood counts.

If you’d like, I can list the specific tests your doctor should order next and what the common prognostic results mean.

question:
I underwent a lung transplant due to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Unfortunately, I later experienced hypercapnic respiratory failure, which ultimately led to my passing. Following my death, an investigator performed an autopsy to study the effects of immune-mediated pulmonary damage. 

During the autopsy, the investigator examined my lungs and noted diffuse eosinophilic scarring in the terminal and respiratory bronchioles. There was also nearly complete luminal obstruction caused by polypoidal plugs of granulation tissue. Additionally, the investigator checked my skin and found no abnormalities. 

These findings were significant in understanding the condition I had experienced leading up to my death. The insights gained from this examination may contribute to further research in similar cases involving lung transplants and immune-related pulmonary issues.
options: A. Transfusion-related acute lung injury B. Recurrence of primary disease C. Hyperacute graft rejection D. Chronic graft rejection E. Acute graft-versus-host disease F. Acute graft rejection
default: Those autopsy findings are characteristic of chronic lung-allograft rejection—obliterative bronchiolitis (constrictive bronchiolitis) with superimposed organizing (proliferative) bronchiolitis (polypoid intraluminal granulation tissue, historically called BOOP). This process produces diffuse small‑airway scarring and near‑complete bronchiolar obstruction, which explains progressive airflow limitation and hypercapnic respiratory failure. The lack of skin abnormalities argues against a systemic process such as graft‑versus‑host disease.

question:
I was admitted to the emergency room after experiencing intense abdominal pain for about eight hours. The pain was severe and radiated to my back. I also felt nauseous and had multiple episodes of vomiting. My medical history had no significant issues prior to this incident.

Upon arrival, the medical team noted that my blood pressure was quite low at 90/60 mm Hg, and my pulse was elevated at 120 beats per minute. My respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute, and I had a slight fever with a temperature of 37.8°C (100°F). During the examination, the doctors found significant tenderness in my epigastric area and noted that my bowel sounds were hypoactive.

As my condition deteriorated, it became necessary to transfer me to the intensive care unit for a month. After being stabilized, I was moved to the general medicine floor. A CT scan of my abdomen revealed a well-circumscribed collection of fluid with a homogeneous density. This sequence of events has left me with a clearer understanding of my condition.
options: A. Pancreatic pseudocyst B. Walled-off necrosis C. Acute necrotic collection D. Pancreatic cancer E. Fistula formation
default:
Most likely diagnosis: acute severe pancreatitis complicated by a pancreatic pseudocyst (a well‑circumscribed, homogeneous fluid collection that develops after pancreatitis).

Why this fits:
- Classic presentation for pancreatitis: severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea/vomiting, epigastric tenderness, hypoactive bowel sounds.  
- The hypotension and tachycardia reflect a severe inflammatory response/shock that can require ICU care.  
- On CT a pancreatic pseudocyst appears as a round, encapsulated, homogeneous fluid collection; by contrast walled‑off necrosis contains heterogeneous debris.

Usual next steps / management points:
- Initial pancreatitis care: aggressive IV fluids, bowel rest (NPO), pain control, monitor/support organ function and treat underlying cause (look for gallstones, alcohol, hypertriglyceridemia, drugs).  
- For the pseudocyst: small and asymptomatic → observation and repeat imaging; symptomatic, enlarging, infected, or persistent (>6 weeks or >6 cm often) → drainage. Preferred drainage options include endoscopic cystogastrostomy with stenting, percutaneous drainage, or surgical drainage depending on anatomy and expertise.  
- If you haven’t already, follow up with a gastroenterologist/hepatopancreatobiliary service and get evaluation for the cause of your pancreatitis and for appropriate timing/route of pseudocyst management.

If you want, tell me timing of the CT (how long after your hospitalization) and whether lab tests (amylase/lipase), ultrasound/ERCP results, or symptoms (fever, growing mass, persistent pain) were present — I can give more specific recommendations.

question:
I am a 36-year-old man who recently experienced massive hematemesis. My medical history includes a gastric ulcer. When I arrived for treatment, my pulse was 115 beats per minute, my respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute, and my temperature was measured at 36°C (96.8°F). My blood pressure was low at 90/59 mm Hg.

During my treatment, I received a transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells. Shortly after the transfusion began, specifically around 5 to 10 minutes later, I started to feel chills and experienced pain in my lower back. I also noticed a decrease in my urine output. My vital signs changed; my pulse increased to 118 beats per minute, my respiratory rate decreased slightly to 19 breaths per minute, and my temperature rose to 38°C (100.4°F). My blood pressure dropped further to 60/40 mm Hg.

These symptoms prompted further evaluation to determine the underlying cause of my condition.
options: A. Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction B. Anaphylactic transfusion reaction C. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction D. Transfusion-associated sepsis E. Transfusion-related acute lung injury
default:
Most likely diagnosis: acute (intravascular) hemolytic transfusion reaction due to ABO incompatibility.

Why: the reaction began within minutes of starting RBCs and produced classic signs of massive intravascular hemolysis — fever/chills, new hypotension and tachycardia, back/flank pain (renal/ureteral/hemoglobinuria pain), decreased urine output — all consistent with rapid complement‑mediated RBC destruction with hemoglobinuria and possible acute tubular injury/DIC.

Key pathophysiology: recipient IgM (or IgG activating complement) against donor RBC antigens → complement activation → intravascular hemolysis → free hemoglobin in plasma/urine, hemoglobinuria → acute kidney injury, hyperkalemia, DIC, shock.

Important immediate actions (do these now if still ongoing)
- Stop the transfusion immediately; keep IV line open with normal saline.
- Notify the blood bank and your clinical team.
- Return blood bag and tubing to blood bank per protocol.
- Send patient blood samples for type & cross, direct antiglobulin test (DAT/Coombs), CBC, CMP (creatinine, K+), bilirubin, LDH, haptoglobin, coagulation studies, and urinalysis/urine hemoglobin.
- Aggressive IV fluids to preserve renal perfusion/urine output; give vasopressors if hypotension persists.
- Monitor urine output; consider diuretics (or mannitol) to maintain urine and urgent dialysis if severe AKI or hyperkalemia develops.
- Treat DIC/supportive care as indicated; admit to ICU.

Differential includes septic transfusion reaction or anaphylaxis, but the rapid onset plus back pain, hemoglobinuria and oliguria points to acute hemolysis from ABO incompatibility as the most likely cause.

question:
I am a 52-year-old woman, and for the past six months, I have been experiencing intermittent diffuse abdominal pain that intensifies after I eat. Along with this pain, I have had several episodes of diarrhea, the most recent of which was bloody. These symptoms began to appear gradually but have worsened recently. As a result of these ongoing issues, I have noticed significant weight loss.

Additionally, I have a medical history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which has been challenging to manage. During my recent check-up, my vital signs were recorded, showing a blood pressure of 100/70 mm Hg, a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8 °F), and a pulse rate of 95 beats per minute. During the physical examination, I appeared to be in severe pain, and the doctor noted mild diffuse abdominal tenderness.

Given the combination of my symptoms and medical history, I am seeking clarification on the most likely diagnosis for my condition.
options: A. Gastroenteritis B. Ischemic bowel disease C. Ulcerative colitis D. Small bowel obstruction E. Acute pancreatitis
default:
Most likely diagnosis: chronic mesenteric ischemia (intestinal angina) — likely from mesenteric vascular compromise (atherosclerotic disease or SLE-associated vasculitis/thrombosis) with ischemic colitis.

Why this fits:
- Classic pattern of post‑prandial, diffuse abdominal pain that causes food‑fear and marked weight loss.
- “Severe pain out of proportion to exam” with only mild abdominal tenderness is characteristic of intestinal ischemia.
- Episodes of bloody diarrhea can reflect ischemic injury to bowel (ischemic colitis).
- Your history of poorly controlled SLE increases risk of vasculitis and thrombotic events affecting mesenteric vessels.

Immediate next steps (urgent):
- Obtain CT angiography (CTA) of the abdomen (mesenteric vessels) — best initial imaging to look for arterial stenosis/occlusion.
- Labs: CBC, metabolic panel, serum lactate, coagulation studies; stool studies if infectious cause suspected.
- Vascular surgery or interventional radiology consult (mesenteric angiography and possible revascularization) if imaging suggests ischemia.
- If acute ischemia is suspected or lactate is rising/clinical status worsens, urgent management (anticoagulation if thrombosis, possible embolectomy/revascularization, or surgery for infarcted bowel) is required.

Differential diagnoses include inflammatory bowel disease and infectious colitis, but the post‑prandial pain, weight loss, and pain severity relative to exam strongly point to mesenteric ischemia. Discuss these findings with your provider urgently for definitive imaging and management.

question:
I am a 51-year-old woman who recently visited the emergency department due to an aggressive cough that has persisted for about 11 years. This cough often produces copious amounts of thick, foamy, yellow-green sputum. I have experienced exacerbations similar to this one over the years, and I notice that the cough tends to worsen in the morning.

Throughout this time, I have sought medical attention multiple times for recurrent bouts of bronchitis, which have required antibiotic treatment. I do not smoke. During my examination, my blood pressure was recorded at 125/78 mm Hg, my pulse rate was 80 beats per minute, my respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute, and my temperature was 36.7°C (98.0°F). 

The doctor listened to my chest and noted crackles and wheezing in the right middle lobe, while the rest of the physical examination results appeared normal. A chest X-ray was performed, revealing irregular opacities in the right middle lobe and diffuse airway thickening. These findings, combined with my medical history, have led to further discussions regarding a potential diagnosis.
options: A. Tuberculosis B. Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency C. Bronchiectasis D. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease E. Chronic bronchitis
default:
Your history (11 years of daily, copious purulent sputum; recurrent “bronchitis” requiring antibiotics; worse in the morning; focal crackles/wheeze in the right middle lobe; chest x‑ray with RML opacities and diffuse airway thickening) is most suggestive of bronchiectasis, particularly localized bronchiectasis of the right middle lobe. Bronchiectasis is characterized by permanently dilated airways that trap mucus and lead to recurrent infections and large-volume purulent sputum.

What to do next (reasonable and commonly recommended steps)
- Get a high-resolution chest CT (HRCT). This is the diagnostic test: it will show bronchial dilation, airway wall thickening, and loss of normal bronchial tapering.
- Obtain sputum for Gram stain, routine culture (and sensitivity), and mycobacterial culture (NTM) before giving antibiotics if possible.
- Pulmonary function testing to assess airflow obstruction and baseline lung function.
- Basic workup for underlying causes if CT confirms bronchiectasis: serum immunoglobulins, testing for cystic fibrosis if clinically indicated, alpha‑1 antitrypsin level, and testing for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (total IgE, Aspergillus IgE) as appropriate.
- Refer to a pulmonologist and consider ENT evaluation if chronic sinus disease is present.

Initial management measures
- Airway clearance techniques (chest physiotherapy, devices, or pulmonary rehab) to help clear sputum.
- Treat acute exacerbations with culture-directed antibiotics; if frequent exacerbations, long‑term macrolide therapy (e.g., azithromycin) may be considered by a specialist.
- Inhaled bronchodilators if there is reversible obstruction; inhaled hypertonic saline or mucolytics for sputum mobilization in select patients.
- Routine vaccinations (influenza, pneumococcal).

When to consider surgery
- If bronchiectasis is truly localized to the right middle lobe and you have repeated, refractory infections despite optimal medical therapy, surgical resection can be considered by a thoracic surgeon/pulmonologist.

If you’d like, I can help you draft questions to ask your pulmonologist, or a checklist of tests to request at your next visit.

question:
I am a 35-year-old man who experienced shortness of breath while playing football with friends. This episode began about an hour into the game. I have had similar instances in the past that required emergency care. 

Upon arriving at the emergency room, my body temperature was recorded at 37.2°C, with a pulse rate of 100 beats per minute and a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. My blood pressure was measured at 110/60 mm Hg. The examination revealed decreased breath sounds on both sides. My peak expiratory flow rate was 200 L/min, and my oxygen saturation was at 89% while breathing room air.

The medical team initiated treatment with nebulization using a short-acting β-agonist. I was also given oxygen via a mask. After oxygen administration, my oxygen levels improved, with a recorded partial pressure of oxygen increasing to 75 mm Hg. 

I am aware that my condition often leads to hospital visits, and I am seeking to understand the underlying cause of these episodes of shortness of breath.
options: A. Asthma attack B. Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning C. Atelectasis D. Neuromuscular disease E. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
default:
Most likely you have bronchial asthma — specifically exercise‑induced bronchospasm on a background of recurrent asthma. The key clues are:
- Recurrent, activity‑triggered shortness of breath
- Decreased breath sounds and a low peak expiratory flow (200 L/min, well below expected for an adult male)
- Hypoxaemia (SpO2 89%) that improved with bronchodilator nebulisation and oxygen
- Good acute response to a short‑acting β2‑agonist (typical for reversible airway obstruction)

What’s happening: asthma causes chronic airway inflammation and hyperresponsiveness. On trigger (exercise, allergen, viral illness), airways constrict, mucus increases and airflow is limited — producing wheeze, reduced peak flow and low oxygen levels. The reversibility with a bronchodilator supports the diagnosis.

Suggested next steps:
- Arrange outpatient spirometry with bronchodilator testing to confirm diagnosis and measure severity.
- Start or optimize controller therapy (inhaled corticosteroid ± long‑acting bronchodilator) if asthma is confirmed, and continue a short‑acting β2‑agonist for rescue.
- Consider allergy testing and asthma action plan (including peak flow targets) to reduce future ER visits.
- Seek urgent care if you develop severe breathlessness, worsening hypoxaemia, difficulty speaking, confusion, or signs of exhaustion despite treatment.

If you want, I can help you interpret spirometry results or suggest an asthma action plan and medication options.

question:
I am a 70-year-old woman, and for the past two weeks, I have been experiencing severe fatigue. Over the last month, I have unintentionally lost about 2 kilograms (4.4 pounds). Three years ago, I was diagnosed with myelodysplastic syndrome. Currently, I do not take any medications aside from aspirin for occasional knee pain. I neither smoke nor drink alcohol.

During my recent visit to the doctor, my vital signs were recorded as normal. However, the examination revealed that my conjunctivae appeared pale. I also had petechiae on the distal parts of my lower extremities and on both my soft and hard palates. When my doctor palpated my neck, they noted bilateral painless cervical lymphadenopathy. An examination of my lungs, heart, and abdomen showed no abnormalities.

The doctor conducted some laboratory studies, but I do not have the results from those tests. I am aware that the findings during my examination raised some concerns, and I am waiting to understand more about what might be causing my symptoms and the changes observed during the physical examination.
options: A. Acute myeloid leukemia B. Aplastic anemia C. Chronic myelogenous leukemia D. Hairy cell leukemia E. Primary myelofibrosis
default:
Thank you — this sounds concerning and warranting prompt hematology evaluation. Based on your history and exam, here are the most likely explanations, what should be done next, and what to watch for.

Most likely causes (in order of likelihood)
- Progression of your myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with worsening bone‑marrow failure causing anemia and thrombocytopenia. This explains the pallor and petechiae.
- Transformation of MDS to acute myeloid leukemia (AML) — MDS can evolve to AML and that often presents with fatigue, weight loss, new lymphadenopathy, and cytopenias.
- Less likely: a new lymphoproliferative disorder (lymphoma or leukemia) or bone‑marrow infiltration by another malignancy or severe viral infection. Aspirin can worsen bleeding/bruising but would not explain anemia or new lymphadenopathy.

Why these fit your findings
- Pale conjunctivae = anemia. Severe fatigue over weeks is typical of significant anemia.
- Petechiae on the palate and lower extremities suggests a low platelet count (often very low, e.g. <20–30 ×10^9/L).
- New, bilateral painless cervical lymphadenopathy is more typical of hematologic malignancy than of simple iron deficiency or medication effects.
- Your prior diagnosis of MDS increases the risk that the marrow function has worsened or transformed.

Key tests you should get urgently
- Complete blood count (CBC) with differential and platelet count (urgent).
- Peripheral blood smear (looking for blasts, abnormal cells, platelet number/appearance).
- Reticulocyte count, iron studies, B12/folate if anemia is present.
- Basic metabolic panel, liver function tests, LDH, uric acid (baseline and to assess tumor burden).
- Coagulation tests (PT/INR, aPTT) if there is active bleeding.
- Viral testing as clinically indicated (HIV, EBV, CMV).
- Most important: bone marrow aspiration and biopsy with flow cytometry and cytogenetics/molecular testing to determine whether MDS has progressed or transformed to AML or another marrow disorder.
- Imaging (CT neck/chest/abdomen ± PET) to evaluate the lymph nodes and look for splenomegaly or other disease sites if lymphoma/lymphadenopathy is prominent.

Immediate practical steps
- Stop aspirin until platelet count is known and you’ve discussed with your physician (aspirin increases bleeding risk).
- Avoid NSAIDs, invasive procedures, or activities with bleeding risk until platelet status is clarified.
- Arrange urgent hematology referral (same day or within 24–48 hours depending on local practice) — if blood counts are very abnormal you should be seen urgently.
- Transfusion support (red cells or platelets) may be needed if you are symptomatic or counts are dangerously low — hematology will advise.

When to seek emergency care now
- New or worsening bleeding (especially oral bleeding, large bruises, black/tarry stools, vomit with blood)
- New shortness of breath, chest pain, collapse, high fever, or sudden marked weakness
If any of these occur go to the ER immediately.

If you like, I can help you prioritize questions to ask your doctor or a short checklist to bring to the hematology appointment.

question:
I am an 8-year-old boy, and I was taken to the emergency department about three hours after experiencing a concerning episode at school. While I was in class, I had a two-minute incident where my right arm moved violently and jerkily. During this time, I was sweating a lot, but I did not lose consciousness. Before the episode began, I felt a chill run down my spine.

After the jerking stopped, I noticed that my right arm felt weak, and I couldn't lift it above my head for about two hours. A few weeks prior to this incident, I had a sore throat, which went away after I took some over-the-counter medicine.

I was born at term, and my mom recalls that I had a similar episode of jerky movements when I was a toddler and had a high fever. There is no significant family history of illnesses, although my father passed away in a car accident about a year ago. When examined at the hospital, my temperature was normal, my pulse was steady, and my blood pressure was measured. Both physical and neurological exams did not reveal any abnormalities. Blood tests for various levels showed everything was within the normal range.
options: A. Sydenham chorea B. Sporadic transient tic disorder C. Conversion disorder D. Hemiplegic migraine E. Focal seizure
default:
Thanks for describing exactly what happened — that helps a lot. Based on your story, the most likely thing is:

Probable diagnosis
- A focal (partial) seizure affecting the part of the brain controlling your right arm. The jerking of the right arm for about two minutes, the chill down your spine beforehand (an “aura”), staying awake during the event, and the temporary weakness in the same arm afterward all fit this pattern.
- The arm weakness that lasted a couple of hours is very likely Todd’s paralysis — a temporary weakness that can follow a focal seizure and usually gets better on its own (often within hours, sometimes up to 48 hours).

Why this fits
- The seizure only involved one arm and you did not lose consciousness: that points to a focal seizure.
- Normal physical exam and blood tests are reassuring and make things like a metabolic cause less likely.
