- Having had a febrile seizure as a toddler doesn’t necessarily mean you have epilepsy now; many children with one febrile seizure do fine long-term.

Next steps (what your parents and doctors will likely do)
- See a pediatric neurologist for evaluation.
- Have an EEG (brain electrical activity test) to look for seizure activity or an area that’s likely to produce seizures.
- Have a brain MRI to rule out any structural cause (for example, a small scar, malformation, or other lesion) that might explain a focal seizure.
- Whether you start seizure medicine depends on the EEG/MRI results and on whether another seizure happens. Many kids do not start daily medicine after a single unprovoked seizure.

Safety and what to do if it happens again
- Seizure first aid: stay calm, protect the head, put something soft under the head, turn the person on their side if possible, don’t put anything in their mouth, don’t hold them down.
- Call for emergency help if the seizure lasts more than 5 minutes, if breathing is very hard or stops, if another seizure starts right away, or if the child is injured or doesn’t wake up normally afterwards.
- Avoid swimming or bathing alone, climbing unsupervised, and let school staff know so they can act safely if another event happens.

About the sore throat and history
- A sore throat weeks ago is unlikely to be the cause. Sydenham chorea (a rare movement problem after strep throat) looks different (random, dance-like movements) and is not the same as a focal seizure.
- The childhood febrile seizure is common and doesn’t necessarily mean you will have epilepsy, though it slightly increases the chance compared with children who never had a febrile seizure.

If you want, tell me who you’ll be seeing next (pediatrician or neurologist) and I can list exact questions to ask or what to bring to the appointment.

question:
I am a 56-year-old man who was brought to the emergency department due to increasing crampy abdominal pain and swelling that had developed over the past two days. I had not passed stool or flatus for over 12 hours and experienced vomiting twice during this period. Notably, I had observed a decrease in the caliber of my stools over the past month.

My medical history is generally unremarkable, except for having undergone an appendectomy eight years ago. I do not take any medications. Upon arrival at the emergency department, my vital signs were recorded: my temperature was 37.5°C (99.5°F), my pulse was 82 beats per minute, my respirations were 19 breaths per minute, and my blood pressure was 110/70 mm Hg.

The examination of my abdomen revealed symmetric distension with active bowel sounds and generalized tenderness, but there was no guarding or rebound tenderness. A leukocyte count was also assessed, showing a count of 10,000/mm³. X-rays of my abdomen were taken in both upright and supine positions. I was informed that these findings would help determine the underlying cause of my recent condition.
options: A. Acute mesenteric ischemia B. Adhesions C. Diverticulitis D. Ogilvie’s syndrome E. Sigmoid tumor
default:
Most likely you have an acute large‑bowel obstruction (LBO), probably due to a colonic lesion (classically a sigmoid carcinoma given your month‑long change in stool caliber). The upright and supine abdominal radiographs are used to distinguish small‑bowel from large‑bowel obstruction and to look for free air (perforation).

What those films would typically show if this is an LBO
- Marked, peripheral dilation of the colon (usually >6 cm in the colon; cecum at highest risk if >9 cm).  
- Haustral markings that do not cross the entire lumen (contrast with valvulae conniventes of small bowel).  
- An abrupt cutoff of colonic gas at the site of obstruction (often seen as transition point).  
- On the upright film: few air‑fluid levels in the colon; on the supine film: diffuse gas‑filled, dilated colon with little or no gas distal to the obstruction.  
- Upright film will also be used to look for free intraperitoneal air under the diaphragm (if perforation), which you do not have clinically at present.

How that differs from small‑bowel obstruction (for comparison)
- SBO: centrally located, multiple dilated small‑bowel loops with valvulae conniventes crossing the lumen and multiple stacked air‑fluid levels on upright film. Prior surgery (appendectomy) can cause adhesions and SBO, but your progressive change in stool caliber favors a colonic lesion.

Recommended next steps
- Urgent CT abdomen/pelvis with IV (and oral if feasible) contrast to confirm level and cause, and to evaluate bowel viability.  
- NPO, IV fluids, electrolyte correction, nasogastric decompression if vomiting, and immediate surgical (or gastroenterology) consultation.  
- Definitive management will depend on CT findings (endoscopic decompression or urgent surgery if complete obstruction or ischemia).

If you want, I can sketch the expected radiographic appearance in more detail or walk through the likely CT findings and treatment options.

question:
I was brought to the emergency department by police officers after acting strangely in public. I was found talking nonsensically to characters on cereal boxes in a store. I am 60 years old, and my medical history includes multiple hospitalizations due to alcohol-related injuries and seizures. 

Upon arrival, my vital signs were checked and found to be within normal limits. During the physical examination, I appeared disheveled and was oriented to my identity but not to the time or place. The neurologic examination revealed that I had nystagmus and severe gait ataxia. 

To assess my condition further, a T1/T2 MRI was performed, which showed evidence of damage to my mammillary bodies. I received appropriate treatment, which helped me recover most of my cognitive functions. However, I continue to experience significant short-term memory deficits. I can still recall events from my past, including the schools and college I attended, my current job, and the names of my family members quite well. Despite these improvements, I struggle with new information and recent events.
options: A. Delirium B. Delirium tremens C. Korsakoff's syndrome D. Schizophrenia E. Wernicke encephalopathy
default:
This is classic Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome from thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency due to chronic alcohol use.

Why: the acute triad—ophthalmoplegia/nystagmus, gait ataxia, and confusion—fits Wernicke encephalopathy. MRI showing mammillary body damage and the persistent profound inability to form new memories (anterograde amnesia) with preserved remote memory and confabulation are characteristic of the chronic amnestic state (Korsakoff syndrome).

Pathophysiology (brief): thiamine deficiency injures diencephalic structures (mammillary bodies, medial dorsal thalamus) and related circuits needed for memory consolidation, so old memories remain but new information cannot be reliably encoded.

Treatment and follow-up: urgent parenteral thiamine (already given), abstinence from alcohol, nutritional support, and cognitive rehabilitation/memory aids. Prognosis: some recovery possible but many patients have persistent anterograde amnesia.

question:
Four days after my admission to the hospital for a pulmonary contusion and whiplash injury from a motor vehicle collision, I began to experience severe pain in my right flank, accompanied by muscle spasms. I also felt nauseous and had two episodes of vomiting, along with noticeable abdominal bloating. Initially, my pain had been well managed with acetaminophen every six hours.

I have a history of umbilical hernia repair surgery from two years ago and take sertraline for depression. At the time of my assessment, my temperature was 36.5°C, pulse was 99 beats per minute, respirations were 17 breaths per minute, and my blood pressure was 102/72 mm Hg. After receiving 0.5 liters of crystalloid fluids, my blood pressure improved to 118/79 mm Hg.

Upon examination, multiple ecchymoses were observed on my anterior abdominal wall, following the course of a seatbelt, and I had additional ecchymoses on both flanks. My bowel sounds were absent, and I experienced tenderness in all four quadrants with voluntary guarding. I was informed that my hemoglobin level was low. An x-ray of my abdomen indicated changes that suggest a possible underlying issue requiring further evaluation.
options:
A. Small bowel perforation B. Intraabdominal adhesions C. Effect of pain medication D. Sigmoid volvulus E. Spinal cord injury F. Retroperitoneal hemorrhage G. Acute mesenteric ischemia
"
default:
You have a picture concerning for a significant intra‑abdominal injury from the MVC—most likely a delayed hollow‑viscus or mesenteric injury (or less likely a retroperitoneal/renal bleed), given the seatbelt‑sign ecchymoses, new diffuse abdominal tenderness with guarding, absent bowel sounds, abdominal distension/nausea/vomiting, and a falling hemoglobin four days after the crash.

Why this matters
- Seatbelt‑sign ecchymoses are strongly associated with bowel/mesenteric injury.  
- Delayed presentation (days later) with ileus/distension, vomiting and peritoneal signs is classic for small‑bowel/mesenteric injury or contained hemorrhage that becomes symptomatic.  
- Low hemoglobin and flank ecchymoses raise concern for ongoing internal bleeding/retroperitoneal hematoma.

Immediate next steps
1. Trauma/acute‑surgery consult urgently.  
2. If hemodynamically stable (BP now 118/79), obtain a contrast‑enhanced CT abdomen/pelvis (IV ± oral/rectal per local protocol) to look for free fluid, bowel wall thickening/mesenteric stranding, active contrast extravasation, free air, or retroperitoneal hematoma.  
3. If hemodynamically unstable or frank peritonitis on exam, proceed to urgent exploratory laparotomy rather than CT.  
4. Simultaneous supportive workup/management: repeat CBC (trend Hgb/Hct), type & cross, coagulation studies, serum lactate, NPO, IV fluids, analgesia, broad‑spectrum IV antibiotics if perforation suspected, nasogastric decompression if vomiting/obstruction, and continuous monitoring.

Tell the team the key concerns (seatbelt sign, dropping hemoglobin, diffuse guarding/absent bowel sounds) so they prioritize urgent imaging and surgical evaluation.

question:
I am a 30-year-old man who recently started taking TMP-SMX for a urinary tract infection. I went to urgent care because I developed a new rash. When I arrived, my vital signs were taken; my blood pressure was 121/80 mm Hg, my pulse was 91 beats per minute, my respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute, and my temperature was 36.7°C (98.2°F). 

During the physical examination, the healthcare provider noted a desquamative skin condition affecting both of my lower extremities. I did not have any immediate discomfort, but the appearance of the rash was concerning to me. After the examination, my medical history and current medications were discussed to determine the possible cause of the rash. 

I was informed that additional tests, including a basic chemistry panel, would be performed to gather more information, although I did not receive any specific results at that time. Overall, I felt the need for a thorough evaluation due to the unexpected development of the rash following the initiation of my antibiotic therapy.
options: A. Dermatitis herpetiformis B. Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS) C. Seborrheic dermatitis D. Atopic dermatitis E. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)
default:
What likely happened
- A new desquamative rash that began after starting trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP‑SMX) is most consistent with a drug eruption. Sulfonamides commonly cause morbilliform rashes and, less commonly, more serious reactions (fixed drug eruption, erythema multiforme, DRESS, Stevens–Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis).

Immediate actions (do these now)
1. Stop TMP‑SMX immediately and do not take any more doses.
2. If you have any of the following go to the emergency department right away:
   - New or worsening blisters, widespread peeling/sloughing of skin, or mucous membrane involvement (mouth, eyes, genitals)
   - Fever, fast heart rate, low blood pressure, difficulty breathing, dizziness, or other systemic illness
   These are red flags for SJS/TEN or other severe drug reactions.

Information that will help make the diagnosis (please answer or bring to clinician)
- When did the rash start relative to the first TMP‑SMX dose?
- Is the rash itchy, painful, or spreading? Any blisters?
- Any mouth, eye, or genital lesions?
- Any fever, chills, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, facial swelling, or breathing problems?
- Any prior reactions to sulfa drugs or other antibiotics? Any HIV, autoimmune disease, or other new medications?

What the urgent care / clinician will likely do next
- Stop the suspected drug.
- Perform or review labs: CBC with differential, basic metabolic panel (kidney function), liver tests; possibly CRP/ESR, and eosinophil count if DRESS is suspected.
- Photograph the rash and consider dermatology referral and/or skin biopsy if uncertain or severe.
- Manage symptoms: topical emollients and topical steroids for localized rash; oral antihistamines for itching.
- If there is concern for SJS/TEN, transfer to hospital (often burn unit or ICU) for supportive care; specialized therapies may be considered.

Short-term symptomatic care if symptoms are mild and no red flags
- Keep skin moisturized, avoid irritants and tight clothing.
- Oral antihistamines (e.g., cetirizine or diphenhydramine at night) for itch.
- Short course of topical low-to-mid potency steroid for inflamed areas if advised by clinician.

Longer-term
- Do not take sulfonamide antibiotics in the future until the reaction is evaluated and classified by a clinician/dermatologist. Document the allergy in your medical record.
- If you need UTI treatment in future, alternatives include nitrofurantoin or a fluoroquinolone or beta‑lactam depending on culture/sensitivity and your renal function — discuss with your provider.

If you want, tell me:
- Exact timing of rash onset after starting TMP‑SMX
- Whether there are blisters or mucosal lesions
- Any lab results you received
I can help interpret the severity and next steps.

question:
I am a 17-year-old girl who was admitted to the emergency department due to severe retrosternal chest pain. The pain started suddenly after I vomited following a large meal. My parents mentioned that I have a very restricted diet and that I frequently induce vomiting after eating. 

When I arrived at the hospital, I felt pale and was in severe distress. The medical team checked my vital signs, which showed a blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg, a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 37.9℃ (100.2℉). During the examination, the doctors noted that my lungs were clear, but they heard a crunching, raspy sound over my chest that matched my heartbeat. My abdomen was soft and not tender, which the doctors took into account during their assessment. 

Given the circumstances and my symptoms, the medical team considered which tests would most likely confirm the diagnosis I was facing.
options: A. Upper endoscopy B. ECG C. Echocardiography D. Contrast esophagram E. Measurement of D-dimer
default:
Most likely diagnosis: Boerhaave syndrome (spontaneous esophageal rupture) — classic after forceful vomiting with sudden retrosternal pain and a Hamman’s crunch (mediastinal air).

Best tests to confirm:
- Initial chest x-ray will often show pneumomediastinum or left pleural effusion.
- Diagnostic test of choice: contrast esophagography with a water‑soluble contrast agent (Gastrografin swallow). If that is negative but suspicion remains high, follow with a thin barium study or chest CT.
- Contrast-enhanced chest CT is also highly sensitive and often done in the ED to evaluate mediastinal air and guide management.

(Management is urgent: NPO, IV fluids, broad‑spectrum antibiotics, and immediate surgical consultation.)

question:
I am a 47-year-old man who recently visited the emergency department due to experiencing urinary and fecal incontinence for the past six hours. Earlier that day, I had fallen at my construction site and sustained injuries to my back and thighs, but I did not seek medical attention at that time. To manage my lower back pain, I took ibuprofen.

Upon arriving at the emergency department, my vital signs were taken, and I was found to have a temperature of 36.9°C, a pulse of 80 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 132/84 mm Hg. During the examination, the doctor noted tenderness over my lumbar spine and weakness in both lower extremities. They observed absent ankle jerk reflexes, while my patellar reflexes were still present. Additionally, I had decreased rectal tone, and an ultrasound of my bladder indicated that it was full.

Given these findings, the medical team began to consider potential diagnoses related to my condition.
options:
A. Spinal epidural abscess B. Cerebellar stroke C. Cauda equina syndrome D. Conus medullaris syndrome E. Anterior spinal cord syndrome F. Brown-Sequard syndrome
"
default:
The presentation is highly suspicious for cauda equina syndrome (CES), an emergency caused by compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots.

Why CES fits:
- Acute urinary retention (full bladder on scan) and fecal incontinence with decreased rectal tone indicate S2–S4 nerve root involvement.
- Bilateral lower‑extremity weakness and absent ankle reflexes (S1) with preserved patellar reflexes (L3–L4) localize the problem to the cauda equina rather than a more rostral spinal cord lesion.
- Recent traumatic fall with lumbar tenderness provides a plausible cause (large central disc herniation, fracture with retropulsion, or hematoma).

Key immediate actions (urgent):
- Emergency MRI of the lumbar spine now (or CT myelogram if MRI unavailable) to identify the site/cause of compression.
- Immediate neurosurgery/spine consult — surgical decompression (eg, laminectomy/discectomy) is typically required urgently; outcomes are much better if decompression occurs promptly (ideally within 24–48 hours).
- Urinary catheterization to decompress bladder and measure post‑void residual.
- Document thorough neurologic exam (saddle anesthesia, motor/sensory levels) and times of symptom onset.
- Basic labs and perioperative clearance as indicated; analgesia and immobilization as needed.

Differential to consider:
- Conus medullaris syndrome (more symmetrical, early sphincter loss, often mixed upper and lower motor signs) — less likely given the preserved knee reflexes and absent ankle jerks.
- Traumatic vertebral fracture with nerve root compression.
- Less likely: peripheral neuropathy alone, spinal cord transection (would usually give upper motor neuron signs), or noncompressive causes.

Bottom line: This is potentially cauda equina syndrome and requires immediate MRI and neurosurgical evaluation. If you haven’t already, tell the ED team that you’re concerned about CES and ask for urgent spine imaging and surgical review. If you want, tell me what the MRI shows and I can help interpret it.

question:
I am a 22-year-old female software analyst who visited a medical clinic to evaluate some symptoms I had been experiencing. For the past two months, I noticed tingling and numbness in both of my hands. These sensations tend to worsen by the end of my workday, but I typically do not feel them on my days off.

I have been living with type I diabetes for the past two years, and I manage my condition with insulin. During my visit, I mentioned that I have been sexually active, but I have also been experiencing irregular periods for the last three months. To address the possibility of pregnancy, a urine pregnancy test was conducted, and the result came back negative.

I am seeking to understand what might be causing the tingling and numbness in my hands, especially considering my diabetes and the other health factors I described.
options: A. Hypothyroidism B. Acute intermittent porphyria C. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis D. Diabetic neuropathy E. Multiple sclerosis
default:
Most likely cause: carpal tunnel syndrome (median nerve compression).
- Why: your symptoms are bilateral, worse by the end of a workday doing repetitive hand/wrist tasks (software/keyboard use), which is classic for carpal tunnel. Typical CTS causes numbness/tingling in the thumb, index, middle and radial half of the ring finger, and may be worse with sustained wrist flexion/extension or at night.

Other possibilities
- Diabetic peripheral neuropathy: possible but less likely as an isolated early-hand symptom. Diabetic neuropathy usually starts in the feet and is symmetric and persistent, not strongly linked to activity during the day. It becomes more likely with longer duration/poor glucose control.
- Cervical radiculopathy or brachial plexus problems: can cause arm/hand numbness but usually has neck pain or a different sensory pattern.
- Vitamin B12 deficiency, hypothyroidism, uremic neuropathy, or other systemic causes — less likely but worth checking if exam or history suggests them.
- Less likely causes: thoracic outlet syndrome, inflammatory neuropathies, compressive lesions.

What to do next
1. Clinic exam: provider will check the sensory distribution (median nerve territory), muscle strength (thenar muscles), reflexes, and perform Phalen’s and Tinel’s tests. This can often distinguish CTS from generalized neuropathy or radiculopathy.
2. Basic tests to consider:
   - HbA1c (to assess diabetes control)
   - Bloodwork if indicated: TSH, vitamin B12, renal function/electrolytes
3. If exam is consistent with CTS or if diagnosis is uncertain: referral for nerve conduction studies/EMG to confirm and grade severity.
4. Initial conservative measures you can start now:
   - Neutral wrist splinting at night (and during work if helpful)
   - Frequent short breaks, ergonomic keyboard/mouse setup, keep wrists neutral
   - Avoid prolonged wrist flexion; do gentle nerve/gliding stretches as advised by a therapist
   - Over-the-counter NSAIDs for pain (if appropriate)
5. If conservative care fails or there is progressive weakness/thenar atrophy: refer to hand surgery for steroid injection or surgical release.

Red flags — seek prompt care if you develop progressive hand weakness, difficulty buttoning/typing, muscle wasting in the thumb area, or spreading numbness.

If you’d like, tell me whether the numbness is concentrated in the thumb/index/middle fingers or more diffuse, whether you wake at night from numbness, and how your blood sugars/HbA1c have been — that will help narrow the likelihood of carpal tunnel versus diabetic neuropathy.

question:
I am a 17-year-old male and recently went to the emergency department due to pain in my left eye. For the past week, the pain has been progressively worsening. I have not noticed any changes in my vision, nor have I experienced difficulty moving my left eye. Additionally, I have not had any recent trauma to the area.

In my lifestyle, I smoke about one pack of cigarettes daily and drink alcohol socially. Over the past month, I have had unprotected sexual encounters with two males and four females. My current medications include loratadine, nasal saline spray, and diphenhydramine.

When I arrived at the hospital, my temperature was recorded at 99.5°F, my blood pressure was 100/55 mmHg, my pulse was 72 beats per minute, and my respirations were 11 per minute. My oxygen saturation was measured at 98% on room air. 

During the physical examination, I was noted to be a healthy young man, and the cardiopulmonary exam was within normal limits. The exam revealed certain findings that were noted on a figure provided by the medical staff. The healthcare team discussed potential diagnoses based on my symptoms and examination results.
options: A. Obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct B. Staphylococcus aureus infection of the inferior rectus C. Sexually transmitted infection D. Thrombosis of a major vessel E. Infection of a hair follicle
default:
I can help, but I need the image (or a description of what the figure showed) to give a more specific diagnosis. Based on what you’ve told me, the most likely possibilities for a week of progressive unilateral eye pain without motility problems or major systemic illness are:

- Herpes simplex keratitis — classically causes unilateral pain, photophobia, and a dendritic corneal ulcer on fluorescein exam. Corneal sensation may be reduced.  
- Bacterial (contact-lens–associated) keratitis — severe pain, focal corneal infiltrate/ulcer and often purulent discharge; progresses quickly. (Important only if you wear contacts.)  
- Gonococcal acute conjunctivitis/keratitis — copious purulent discharge and rapid corneal involvement; consider given unprotected sex.  
- Noninfectious causes less likely given progressive pain (corneal abrasion, uveitis/iritis — typically with ciliary flush and photophobia; angle-closure glaucoma would usually have vision changes and a mid-dilated pupil).

What I need from you now
- Please upload the figure or describe what the clinicians documented (fluorescein staining/dendritic pattern, corneal opacity, discharge, eyelid swelling, pupil size/reactivity, visual acuity).  
- Tell me whether you wear contact lenses, have photophobia, eye discharge (and its character), any previous cold sores or genital herpes, or recent skin lesions.

Immediate advice
- If you have any sudden vision loss, worsening pain, marked redness, or a lot of purulent drainage, seek ophthalmology/ED care now.  
- Don’t put steroid eye drops in the affected eye unless prescribed by an ophthalmologist (can worsen HSV and bacterial infections).  
- If you haven’t already been evaluated with slit-lamp/fluorescein exam, you should be seen by eye care urgently.

If you send the image/description, I’ll give the most likely diagnosis and typical next steps/treatment.

question:
I am a 17-year-old rugby player, and I recently experienced an injury during a game. While running, I rolled my ankle, which caused me to limp into the emergency room for evaluation. The medical staff assessed my injury and noted that the mechanism of injury involved both ankle plantar flexion and inversion. 

During the examination, they checked for point tenderness around the medial and lateral malleolus, but there was none present. They performed an anterior drawer test on my ankle, which returned a positive result, indicating some instability. However, the talar tilt test was negative, suggesting that certain ligamentous structures were intact. 

Based on these findings, the medical team concluded that I likely sustained a specific type of ankle injury, although the exact nature of the injury was not detailed in the conversation. Overall, the experience left me concerned about my recovery and the impact this injury might have on my ability to play rugby in the future.
options: A. Anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) sprain B. Calcaneofibular ligament (CFL) sprain C. Deltoid ligament sprain D. Tibia fracture E. Fibula fracture
default:
What this most likely is
- Your mechanism (plantarflexion + inversion) plus a positive anterior drawer and a negative talar tilt pretty much point to an acute lateral ankle sprain — specifically damage to the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL).  
- A positive anterior drawer test = ATFL laxity/partial tear; a negative talar tilt suggests the calcaneofibular ligament is intact. No point tenderness over the malleoli lowers the likelihood of an ankle fracture (Ottawa rules).

What that means for recovery
- Most isolated ATFL sprains in young athletes do well with non‑operative treatment. Expect roughly:
  - Mild (sprain/stretch): days–2 weeks
  - Moderate (partial tear): ~2–6 weeks
  - Severe (complete tear with instability): 6+ weeks, sometimes longer and possibly surgery if instability persists
- Given your exam (positive drawer, intact talar tilt) you likely sit in the mild–moderate (grade II) range — full recovery and return to rugby is very common with proper rehab.

Immediate steps and short-term care
- Protect and reduce swelling (first 48–72 hours): relative rest, ice, compression, elevation (RICE). Avoid prolonged immobilization.
- Use a supportive brace or lace-up boot for a short period (days–2 weeks) if painful or unstable.
- Begin pain‑guided range of motion and then progressive strengthening ASAP — early controlled mobility speeds recovery.

Rehabilitation and return to play
- Start physiotherapy early for:
  - ROM, progressive strengthening (peroneals, calf), proprioception/balance, and sport‑specific agility drills.
- Return-to-play criteria (typical):
  - Pain-free running and cutting, symmetric ankle ROM and strength (near 90–100% vs uninjured side), ability to do sport-specific drills and pass single‑leg hop tests without instability or apprehension.
- Use external support (taping or brace) for your first games back and during a season if you’ve had prior sprains — this reduces reinjury risk.

When to get further testing or specialist input
- If you can’t bear weight immediately, have persistent swelling/pain, numbness, or bony tenderness over the malleoli → get x‑rays.  
- If instability or pain persists despite good rehab (weeks–months), see sports medicine/orthopedics; MRI can assess ligament extent and look for cartilage or other injuries. Surgical repair (e.g., Broström) is considered for chronic mechanical instability.

Practical reassurance
- At 17 and with proper supervised rehab, prognosis for returning to rugby is very good. Follow your physio plan, be cautious with early return, and use a brace/taping early on to lower the chance of recurrence.

If you want, tell me how severe your pain and swelling were, whether you could bear weight at the ER, and whether they gave a specific grade or brace — I can give a more tailored timeline and rehab plan.

question:
I am a 62-year-old man who went to the emergency department due to colicky pain in my lower abdomen and noticeable abdominal distension that had been occurring for the past 12 hours. I have a history of chronic constipation, for which I regularly take lactulose and senna laxatives. When I arrived at the hospital, my temperature was recorded at 37.1°C (98.7°F), my blood pressure was 110/60 mm Hg, and my pulse was 85 beats per minute.

During the physical examination, the doctor observed diffuse abdominal distension and tenderness, and I noticed that my bowel sounds were faint. After these observations, I underwent a plain abdominal radiograph to assess my condition further. The medical team was evaluating the situation to determine the most likely diagnosis related to my symptoms.
options: A. Intussusception B. Infectious colitis C. Bowel adhesions D. Volvulus E. Acute diverticulitis
default:
Most likely diagnosis: sigmoid volvulus (acute large‑bowel obstruction).

Why: elderly patient with chronic constipation and laxative use, acute colicky pain with marked abdominal distension and diminished bowel sounds — classic for sigmoid volvulus. The plain abdominal film in this setting typically shows a massively dilated, inverted U– or “coffee‑bean”–shaped loop of colon with the apex directed toward the right upper quadrant and little gas distally.

Typical next steps: urgent assessment for ischemia/peritonitis; if none, endoscopic detorsion (flexible sigmoidoscopy) is usually attempted, with elective sigmoid resection recommended to prevent recurrence.

question:
I am a 16-year-old girl, and I was brought to the physician by my mother because I have not yet had my menstrual period. At birth, I was diagnosed with partial labial fusion and clitoromegaly. My mother mentioned that during her pregnancy with me, she noticed abnormal hair growth on her chin. I have been experiencing severe acne, which has been quite distressing. 

Three years ago, I broke my wrist after a minor injury, and last year, I sustained a spinal compression fracture while lifting a box during a move. Currently, I am taking oral isotretinoin for my acne and an oral contraceptive. In terms of growth, I am at the 97th percentile for height and the 50th percentile for weight. 

During the physical examination, the doctor observed numerous inflamed pustules on my face and upper back. My breast development is at Tanner stage I. I chose not to undergo a pelvic examination. A pelvic ultrasound was performed, which revealed that I have multiple cysts on my ovaries and a normal uterus.
options: A. Polycystic ovary syndrome B. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia C. Müllerian agenesis D. Hyperprolactinemia E. Imperforate hymen F. Turner syndrome G. Pregnancy H. Aromatase deficiency
default:
Most likely diagnosis: placental aromatase deficiency (CYP19A1 mutation) causing estrogen deficiency with prenatal and postnatal androgen excess.

Why: maternal virilization during pregnancy + a 46,XX infant with ambiguous/virilized external genitalia at birth is classic for fetal placental aromatase deficiency (placenta can’t convert androgens to estrogens). Lack of estrogen explains absent breast development (Tanner I), tall stature and recurrent low‑trauma fractures (failure of epiphyseal closure and low bone mass). Ovarian cysts/polycystic appearance result from excess gonadotropin stimulation of androgen‑producing ovaries; peripheral/high androgen levels account for acne and clitoromegaly.

Key next steps
- Labs: karyotype to confirm 46,XX, serum estradiol (low), testosterone and androstenedione (high), DHEA‑S, LH/FSH.  
- Genetic testing for CYP19A1 (aromatase) mutation.  
- Bone density (DEXA) to assess osteoporosis.  
- Refer to pediatric/endocrine specialists, gynecology and genetics.

Treatment principles
- Start estrogen replacement (pubertal induction with physiologic estrogen dosing) to develop breasts, close epiphyses appropriately, reduce gonadotropin drive and protect bone. Treatment should be supervised by a pediatric/endocrine team.  
- Surgical options for genital appearance can be discussed with gynecology/urology if desired.  
- Continue contraception counseling (isotretinoin is teratogenic — strict pregnancy prevention program if retained).  
- Monitor hormone levels, bone density, and psychosocial support.

If you want, I can lay out specific blood tests to order and an expected hormonal pattern, or help you prepare questions for your endocrinology visit.

question:
I am a 72-year-old woman who visited the emergency department four hours after experiencing a sudden onset of a diffuse, dull, throbbing headache. Along with the headache, I noticed blurred vision, nausea, and had one episode of vomiting. My medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which I take hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. 

I have been a smoker for 30 years, consuming one pack of cigarettes daily, and I drink 1 to 2 glasses of wine each day. Upon arrival at the hospital, my temperature was recorded at 36.6 °C (97.9 °F), my pulse was 90 beats per minute, my respirations were 14 per minute, and my blood pressure was elevated at 185/110 mm Hg. 

During the examination, the doctor performed a fundoscopic examination, which revealed bilateral blurring of the optic disc margins. The physical and neurologic examinations showed no other abnormalities. Additionally, a complete blood count and serum tests for electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine were found to be within the reference range. A urinalysis indicated 2+ protein but did not show the presence of white blood cells or red blood cells.
options:
A. Ischemic stroke B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage C. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension D. Migraine headache E. Hypertensive emergency F. Transient ischemic attack G. Giant cell arteritis
"
default:
Most likely diagnosis
- Hypertensive emergency (malignant hypertension) with acute target‑organ injury — evidence: very high BP (185/110) plus acute headache, visual disturbance and bilateral papilledema. The nausea/vomiting and visual symptoms can reflect hypertensive encephalopathy or posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES).

Why this matters
- Papilledema indicates raised intracranial pressure/acute end‑organ damage and makes this an emergency that requires urgent, controlled BP lowering and inpatient management.

Immediate management (what I would expect the ED/ICU team to do right away)
1. Admit to monitored setting (ED resuscitation area or ICU) with continuous BP and neurological monitoring.
2. Start controlled IV antihypertensive therapy (do not give rapid‑acting oral nifedipine). Typical first‑line options:
   - IV nicardipine infusion (easy titration) or
   - IV labetalol (bolus ± infusion).
   - Sodium nitroprusside or fenoldopam are alternatives if needed.
3. BP targets: reduce mean arterial pressure by no more than ~25% in the first hour, then aim for ~160/100–110 mm Hg over the next 2–6 hours (unless a different target is indicated by stroke/MI protocols).
4. Urgent neuroimaging: noncontrast head CT to exclude intracranial hemorrhage; MRI (with FLAIR) if PRES is suspected.
5. Obtain/monitor labs: repeat basic metabolic panel (creatinine), urinalysis (quantify protein, look for hematuria), ECG and troponin, CBC, consider urine albumin/creatinine ratio. Monitor urine output and electrolytes while treating.
6. Consult neurology and ophthalmology (for papilledema/visual loss) and involve nephrology if renal injury or heavy proteinuria is confirmed.
7. Avoid overly rapid BP lowering (risk of cerebral/renal ischemia). Reassess neuro status frequently.

Longer‑term considerations
- After stabilization, reassess antihypertensive regimen and adherence; escalate chronic BP control with oral agents once stabilized.
- Evaluate for secondary causes of severe HTN if clinically indicated.
- Smoking cessation, alcohol moderation, glucose control, and routine follow-up with primary care/cardiology.

If you are the patient: you should be admitted now for urgent IV treatment and brain imaging. If you have further questions about the medicines you may receive or what imaging will show, tell me and I can explain.

question:
I am a 24-year-old man who went to the emergency department due to worsening shortness of breath and an intermittent cough that produced blood-tinged sputum over the past 10 days. During this period, I experienced three episodes of blood in my urine. 

I had been diagnosed with latent tuberculosis six years ago after a positive tuberculin skin test and received treatment at that time. I do not take any medications currently. My family history includes my maternal aunt, who has systemic lupus erythematosus. 

Upon examination in the emergency department, my temperature was recorded at 37°C (98.6°F), my pulse was 92 beats per minute, and my respirations were elevated at 28 breaths per minute. My blood pressure was measured at 152/90 mm Hg. The doctor noted diffuse crackles in both lung bases during the examination. 

I underwent several tests, including blood and urine analyses, and a chest X-ray, which showed patchy pulmonary infiltrates in both lungs. Additionally, a renal biopsy revealed linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane. These findings were concerning, and I was informed that further evaluation was necessary to determine the most likely diagnosis.
options:
A. Goodpasture syndrome B. Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis C. IgA nephropathy D. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis E. Reactivated tuberculosis F. Microscopic polyangiitis G. Lupus nephritis
"
default:
Most likely diagnosis: Goodpasture syndrome (anti–glomerular basement membrane disease).

Why: the triad of hemoptysis with bilateral pulmonary infiltrates (alveolar hemorrhage), hematuria/renal involvement, and a renal biopsy showing linear IgG deposition along the glomerular basement membrane is classic for anti‑GBM disease. This targets the alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen in alveolar and glomerular basement membranes.

Next steps and management: check circulating anti‑GBM antibodies to confirm, and treat urgently with plasmapheresis plus high‑dose corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide to remove antibody and suppress further production. Early treatment improves pulmonary recovery and can limit irreversible renal damage.

question:
I visited the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain that I had developed 12 hours prior. The pain was constant and I rated it a 7 out of 10. Alongside the pain, I experienced nausea and had vomited twice. In the last four hours, I had two episodes of nonbloody diarrhea, and I have a 12-month history of intermittent constipation.

I do not have any sick contacts or a history of recent travel. My past medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, mild intermittent asthma, and allergic rhinitis. My diet mainly consists of high-fat foods, and I do not smoke; I drink 1 to 2 glasses of wine per week and do not use illicit drugs. My current medications include lisinopril, metformin, an albuterol inhaler, fexofenadine, and psyllium husk fiber. I have no known drug allergies.

During the physical examination, I was lying back in the hospital bed and appeared uncomfortable. My temperature was elevated at 38.4°C (101.1°F). The examination revealed tenderness in the left lower quadrant of my abdomen, but there was no guarding or rebound tenderness. My extremities showed no edema, and I was alert and oriented throughout the assessment.
options: A. Ischemic colitis B. Crohn disease C. Cholecystitis D. Irritable bowel syndrome E. Appendicitis F. Ulcerative colitis G. Diverticulitis
default:
Thanks — this presentation most strongly suggests acute left‑sided colonic pathology, with the leading diagnosis being acute sigmoid diverticulitis. Reasoning:
- Localized constant LLQ pain, fever, nausea/vomiting, and recent diarrhea in a patient with intermittent constipation fit typical diverticulitis.
- Absence of guarding/rebound and relatively short symptom duration favor an uncomplicated process, but fever and significant pain could still justify urgent workup.

Other important differentials
- Infectious gastroenteritis
- Ischemic colitis (risk increased by HTN/DM)
- Inflammatory bowel disease flare
- Ovarian/testicular or gynecologic pathology (if applicable)
- Ureteral stone with referred pain
- Constipation with colonic obstruction / sigmoid volvulus (given constipation history)

Recommended next steps in the ED
- Targeted tests:
  - CBC with differential (look for leukocytosis)
  - Basic metabolic panel (for hydration/renal function)
  - CRP (if available) and lactate if concerned for ischemia or sepsis
  - Urinalysis (to exclude urinary source)
  - Pregnancy test in women of childbearing potential
  - Blood cultures if febrile and systemically ill
- Imaging:
  - CT abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast (and oral/rectal contrast per local protocol) — best test to confirm diverticulitis and to look for complications (abscess, perforation, fistula, obstruction).
- Initial treatment while workup is pending:
  - IV fluids if dehydrated or vomiting
  - Analgesia (e.g., IV acetaminophen and/or opioids as needed)
  - Antiemetic for nausea
  - NPO until imaging if severe pain or concern for complication
  - Antibiotics: if CT confirms uncomplicated diverticulitis and the patient is low risk, recent evidence allows selective nonuse of antibiotics; however, given fever, moderate pain, diabetes, and ED presentation, many clinicians would start empiric broad‑spectrum IV antibiotics and admit or observe until imaging results (e.g., a beta‑lactam/beta‑lactamase inhibitor or ciprofloxacin + metronidazole per local guidelines).
- Consult surgery if CT shows complications (abscess, perforation, peritonitis, obstruction) or if clinical deterioration.

Disposition guidance
- Uncomplicated diverticulitis, stable, tolerating oral intake, adequate social support: possible outpatient management with close follow‑up (some clinicians prescribe oral antibiotics; others do not).
- Admit for IV antibiotics, observation, or surgery if: peritonitis, high fever/marked leukocytosis, immunosuppression (diabetes increases risk), inability to tolerate oral intake, severe pain, or CT evidence of complication.

Red flags that warrant immediate re-evaluation or admission
- Worsening or diffuse abdominal pain, rigors, persistent high fever, inability to tolerate oral intake, syncope/dizziness, signs of sepsis, bloody stools, or peritoneal signs on exam.

Questions I would ask you (or your clinicians to ask)
- Age and sex; last menstrual period and pregnancy status if female
- Any prior episodes of similar pain or known diverticulosis
- Bowel movement pattern immediately prior to ED visit (obstructive symptoms)
- Current medications beyond those listed (steroids, immunosuppressants)
- Recent weight loss, change in bowel habits, or rectal bleeding

If you want, tell me your age/sex and whether you had a CT scan or blood tests in the ED and I can give more specific advice about likely diagnosis and next steps.

question:
I am a 55-year-old man who recently visited the office for an eye exam. Over the past few weeks, I have experienced some difficulty seeing, although I have not felt any pain associated with my vision changes. I have a history of HIV, which I was diagnosed with about 20 years ago due to my intravenous drug use. I stopped using drugs 10 years ago, but I have not been consistent with my medication regimen.

During my visit, the healthcare provider noted that my last CD4+ count was 42, recorded six months prior. My vital signs were within normal ranges, and I underwent a fundoscopic exam as part of the eye examination. The results showed that I have experienced some loss of both central and peripheral vision. The provider discussed potential diagnoses related to my symptoms and medical history.
options: A. Retinal vein occlusion B. Retinal detachment C. Acute angle closure glaucoma D. CMV retinitis E. HSV retinitis
default:
Most likely diagnosis
- Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. In people with AIDS and CD4 counts <50, CMV is the most common cause of painless progressive loss of central and peripheral vision. Fundoscopic findings classically include fluffy, yellow-white retinal lesions with hemorrhage (“pizza‑pie” or “brushfire” appearance).

Why this is most likely
- Your CD4 count of 42 and painless, progressive visual loss fit CMV retinitis. Other possibilities (HSV/VZV necrotizing retinitis, toxoplasma chorioretinitis, HIV retinopathy) are less likely but can look similar; an urgent ophthalmology exam helps differentiate.

What needs to happen now
1. Urgent ophthalmology referral (same day or within 24–48 hours). CMV retinitis is an ophthalmic emergency.
2. Start antiviral therapy promptly if CMV retinitis is confirmed or strongly suspected:
   - Oral valganciclovir is commonly used (induction 900 mg twice daily for ~21 days, then maintenance 900 mg daily), adjusted for renal function.
   - IV ganciclovir (e.g., 5 mg/kg IV q12h) or intravitreal ganciclovir injections may be used for severe or sight‑threatening disease. Foscarnet or cidofovir are alternatives for ganciclovir-resistant disease.
3. Reassess and optimize HIV care (restart/adjust antiretroviral therapy) in coordination with ID/HIV and ophthalmology — immune recovery reduces recurrent CMV but timing should be coordinated because of possible IRIS.
4. Baseline and monitoring labs: CBC (ganciclovir can cause neutropenia), renal function (dose adjustments; foscarnet nephrotoxic), and CMV PCR or ocular sampling if needed. Repeat CD4 and HIV viral load.

Prognosis and prevention
- Without treatment CMV retinitis often causes progressive visual loss and blindness. With prompt antiviral therapy vision can often be stabilized, though scarring may be permanent. Recurrence is common until CD4 counts recover (generally >100) on effective ART.

If you want, I can help you draft questions for your ophthalmology/ID visit, summarize typical medication side effects to watch for, or review what to expect in the eye exam and follow-up.

question:
I am a 45-year-old woman who has been concerned about my inguinal hernia. Two months ago, I went to the emergency department because I noticed a swelling in my left lower abdomen. The doctors at the hospital were able to easily reduce the mass and referred me to the general surgery clinic for an elective surgical repair. Since my condition was not deemed urgent, I was placed on a waiting list for surgery.

Despite this reassurance, I find myself repeatedly visiting the clinic and the emergency department, anxious that my bowels might be trapped and dying. Each time I go, the medical staff reassures me, and any protrusion is quickly reduced. In addition to my hernia concerns, I have a history of abdominal pain and inconsistent bowel habits, which I have discussed with my primary care physician multiple times. However, no specific cause has been identified for these symptoms.

I continue to experience intermittent abdominal discomfort and spend several hours each day worrying about my health and what might be happening to me. I do not have any other significant medical history, but the ongoing anxiety about my condition has been challenging to manage.
options: A. Conversion disorder B. Malingering disorder C. Factitious disorder D. Illness anxiety disorder E. Somatic symptom disorder
default:
You’re describing two linked problems: (1) a real, reducible left inguinal hernia that has been judged safe for elective repair, and (2) ongoing worry and repeated reassurance‑seeking about that hernia (plus chronic abdominal symptoms). That combination is very distressing and is common — the medical facts can be reassuring, but anxiety keeps driving repeat clinic/ED visits.

What’s true medically
- A reducible inguinal hernia that was easily pushed back and judged non‑urgent usually has a low short‑term risk of strangulation, which is why surgery was scheduled electively.
- Nonetheless there is always a small risk over time, so elective repair is reasonable.
- Urgent care is required if the hernia becomes incarcerated/strangulated (see red flags below).

Clear red flags that do require immediate ED care
Go to the ED right away if you have any of:
- A bulge that you cannot push back in (irreducible/incarcerated hernia)
- Severe, constant pain at the hernia site
- Nausea and vomiting
- Inability to pass gas or stool (bowel obstruction)
- Fever or increasing redness, warmth, or dark discoloration of the skin over the lump

How to reduce your anxiety and unnecessary visits
1. Create a “safety plan” with your surgeon/PCP
   - Ask for a single named contact (nurse/clinic phone) and an estimated timeline for surgery. Get written instructions about red flags and when to call/come in.
   - Request a preoperative phone check to confirm you’re on the list and what could change scheduling.

2. Limit reassurance‑seeking
   - Agree with yourself to call the clinic first (not ED) for non‑urgent questions, and only visit ED for red-flag symptoms above.
   - Keep a log when urges to go to ED arise (what you were thinking/feeling) — this helps reduce the urge over time.

3. Practical self-care for abdominal symptoms
   - Regular meals, fiber and hydration, exercise, and sleep hygiene often help bowel consistency and reduce sensations that trigger worry.
   - Track symptoms in a simple diary (time, foods, bowel movement, pain) to show your PCP — patterns often emerge.

4. Psychological treatments that work
   - Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for health anxiety is the best-evidenced treatment: it teaches exposure to feared sensations, reduces checking and reassurance-seeking, and changes unhelpful thoughts.
   - Mindfulness, acceptance strategies, and behavioral experiments are also helpful.
   - If anxiety is severe or persistent, SSRIs (e.g., sertraline, fluoxetine) can be effective; discuss medication with your PCP or a psychiatrist.

5. Short-term coping techniques
   - Grounding/breathing: slow 4‑4‑6 breaths (inhale 4s, hold 4s, exhale 6s) for several minutes.
   - 5‑4‑3‑2‑1 grounding (name 5 things you see, 4 you feel, etc.).
   - Distract with a planned activity for 30–60 minutes when worry spikes.

What you might do next
- Ask your surgeon/clinic for a written safety plan, estimated wait time, and a named contact.
- Book a referral for CBT (look for therapists experienced with health anxiety/illness anxiety or somatic symptom disorder).
- Talk with your PCP about whether a short trial of an SSRI or referral to psychiatry is appropriate.
- If you want, I can help you draft a short script to use when you call the clinic or ED, or a checklist of red flags and coping steps to carry with you.

You’re not “overreacting” — this is understandable given the physical symptom plus anxiety. With a concrete plan and targeted treatment (CBT ± medication), most people get much better and stop needing frequent reassurance. Would you like help drafting a safety‑plan message to send to your surgeon or a short script to use at the ED?

question:
I am a 72-year-old man who was involved in a traffic collision. After the accident, I was transported to the emergency room by ambulance. Upon arrival, I was in shock and comatose. The medical team examined me and noted a heart rate of 60 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 70 over 40 mm Hg. Despite their resuscitative efforts, I did not survive.

Following my death, an autopsy was performed, which revealed multiple internal hemorrhages and signs of ischemic damage in my lungs, kidneys, and brain. The examination of my heart showed significant anomalies. The medical staff suggested that acute hypovolemia was likely the cause of the ischemic changes observed in my organs. However, they were also interested in understanding the underlying reason for the gross anomaly found in my heart.
options: A. Aortic valve regurgitation B. Mitral valve stenosis C. Senile calcific aortic stenosis D. Accumulation of amyloid in the myocardium E. Genetic mutation
default:
Most likely the gross cardiac finding was concentric left‑ventricular hypertrophy. The usual underlying reason for that appearance in an older person is long‑standing pressure overload — most commonly chronic systemic hypertension (or less commonly aortic stenosis). 

Pathophysiology in brief: persistent elevated afterload causes cardiomyocytes to add sarcomeres in parallel, producing a thickened ventricular wall with a smaller chamber and increased interstitial fibrosis. Microscopically you’d see enlarged myocytes with boxcar nuclei and fibrosis. Functionally this produces decreased ventricular compliance (diastolic dysfunction) and greater susceptibility to ischemia under stress (such as acute hypovolemia).

question:
I am a 45-year-old man who was brought to the emergency room by my wife due to confusion that had developed over the past day. Upon arrival, I was found to have a fever, with an oral temperature of 103.6 degrees Fahrenheit. My vital signs were otherwise stable. During the physical examination, the doctor noted some unusual lesions on my skin that I had never seen before. Additionally, I experienced subtle weakness on the right side of my body, which affected both my upper and lower extremities.

While in the emergency room, I underwent various tests. The healthcare team informed me that my blood counts were concerning, particularly my hemoglobin level, which was significantly low. They mentioned that both my PT/INR and PTT results were normal, which offered some reassurance. I was not aware of any previous health issues that could have led to my current state, and it was alarming to find myself experiencing these symptoms. The medical team was focused on determining the underlying cause of my condition, and I was waiting for further assessment and diagnosis.
options: A. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura B. Disseminated intravascular coagulation C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura D. Hemolytic uremic syndrome E. Evan's syndrome
default:
The combination of high fever, new confusion and a new focal neurologic deficit (right‑sided weakness), plus new unexplained skin lesions, strongly raises concern for a bloodstream infection with septic embolization—most classically infective endocarditis. In that scenario vegetations on a heart valve seed bacteria into the blood (causing fever and skin lesions such as Janeway lesions or splinter hemorrhages) and can embolize to the brain (causing focal deficits). Your normal PT/INR and PTT make disseminated intravascular coagulation less likely, but the low hemoglobin is important to evaluate (it may be chronic, due to inflammation or hemolysis, or less commonly related to acute blood loss).

What the team will or should do urgently
- Obtain blood cultures (ideally 3 sets from separate sites) before giving antibiotics.  
- Start empiric IV antibiotics promptly if sepsis/endocarditis is suspected (choices guided by local antibiogram and risk factors; infectious disease will direct this).  
- Urgent neuroimaging (noncontrast head CT initially, and MRI brain when feasible) to look for ischemic stroke, hemorrhage, or brain abscess.  
- Echocardiography: transthoracic (TTE) first, and transesophageal (TEE) if TTE is nondiagnostic or suspicion remains high. TEE is more sensitive for vegetations.  
- Blood tests: repeat CBC with differential and platelet count, blood chemistry, liver tests, inflammatory markers, blood bank type and crossmatch if transfusion may be needed. Evaluate hemolysis if suspected (reticulocyte count, peripheral smear, LDH, haptoglobin, bilirubin, direct Coombs).  
- Urgent consultations: neurology (for focal deficit/stroke management) and infectious disease/cardiology (for endocarditis management and possible surgical evaluation).  
- If the skin lesions can be sampled (swab/biopsy), culture/histology may help identify the organism.

Other conditions to consider (less likely but important)
- Meningococcemia can cause fever, confusion and a petechial/purpuric rash, but often causes abnormal coagulation and very rapid deterioration.  
- Brain abscess/encephalitis from other sources can cause fever and focal deficits; the diagnostic steps above (imaging, cultures, LP only if safe) will help distinguish these.

Immediate priorities for you now
- Ensure blood cultures were drawn before antibiotics.  
- Make sure urgent CT/MRI and an echocardiogram are arranged.  
- Ask that neurology and infectious disease be involved.  
- If you have risk factors (recent dental work, IV drug use, prosthetic valves, indwelling catheters), tell the team—this influences likely organisms and treatment.

Tell your team about any prior anemia, recent procedures, dental infections or injections, and any medications (especially immunosuppressants). If you’d like, tell me the lab values (CBC, platelets, blood cultures if available) and imaging results and I can help interpret them.

question:
I am a 60-year-old woman who recently went to the emergency department because I had been experiencing progressive shortness of breath and a dry cough for the past week. I noticed that my symptoms worsened with physical activity but improved when I rested. 

Two years ago, I was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease, and I had just started regular dialysis treatment. When I arrived at the emergency department, my pulse rate was measured at 105 beats per minute, my blood pressure was 110 over 70 mm Hg, my respiratory rate was 30 breaths per minute, and my temperature was 37.8°C (100.0°F). 

During the respiratory examination, the doctor noted dullness on percussion, decreased vocal tactile fremitus, and decreased breath sounds over the base of my right lung. The remainder of the physical exam was normal. 

I am uncertain about the exact cause of my symptoms, but I am here seeking help for my condition.
options: A. Primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP) B. Pleural effusion C. Pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) D. Pneumonia E. Acute bronchitis
default:
Most likely diagnosis: pleural effusion of the right lower hemithorax.

Why: the classic physical findings you describe—dullness to percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, and decreased breath sounds over the right base—are typical for fluid in the pleural space. Your progressive dyspnea and tachypnea also fit. In a patient on dialysis several causes are possible (see below).

Most important immediate next steps
- Get a chest x‑ray (upright with lateral decubitus if needed) or bedside thoracic ultrasound to confirm and estimate the size of the effusion. Ultrasound is most sensitive at the bedside.
- Because this is a new, unilateral effusion and you have fever and respiratory symptoms, diagnostic thoracentesis (removal of a sample of pleural fluid) is indicated unless the effusion is tiny and clearly due to volume overload. Fluid should be sent for cell count, Gram stain/culture, protein, LDH, glucose, pH and cytology so it can be classified by Light’s criteria and checked for infection or malignancy.
- If you are in respiratory distress or the effusion is large, therapeutic thoracentesis (removing larger volume to relieve symptoms) should be done urgently.

Likely causes to consider (given your history of chronic kidney disease on dialysis)
- Volume overload/transudative effusion from fluid retention (more often bilateral but can be asymmetric) — treat by intensifying dialysis/ultrafiltration and salt/water restriction.
- Parapneumonic effusion or empyema (exudate) associated with pneumonia — more likely when fever and cough are present; requires antibiotics and often drainage if complicated.
- Uremic pleuritis (exudative) — can occur in advanced CKD; diagnosed by pleural-fluid analysis and clinical context.
- Less likely but possible: pulmonary embolism, malignancy, or other inflammatory causes.

How results will guide treatment
- Transudate → treat underlying cause (optimize dialysis/volume status, treat heart failure).
- Exudate → evaluate for infection, malignancy, or inflammation. If infected or complicated parapneumonic effusion (low pH, low glucose, positive culture, or frank pus) you will need chest-tube drainage plus antibiotics.

Red flags — seek immediate care if you develop:
- Worsening shortness of breath, rapid breathing, lightheadedness, or blue lips/fingertips
- High fevers, severe chest pain, or coughing up blood

I recommend you have the chest x‑ray/ultrasound and a prompt thoracentesis arranged and follow up with the ED/pulmonology team so they can analyze the fluid and start the appropriate treatment.

question:
I was taken to the physician for a follow-up examination after experiencing recurrent asthma attacks. My mother mentioned that I had been having mild abdominal pain for the past two weeks. At the time of the visit, I was using daily inhaled fluticasone and inhaled albuterol as needed for my asthma.

During the examination, the physician noted that I appeared well. My temperature was measured at 37°C, my pulse was 100 beats per minute, and my blood pressure was recorded at 130/85 mm Hg. The doctor listened to my lungs and found them clear, with no signs of murmurs, rubs, or gallops in my heart. 

When it came to my abdomen, the doctor found a smooth, nontender mass on the left side that did not cross the midline. The rest of the examination showed no abnormalities. The physician also reviewed some lab results, which indicated that my complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine were all within the reference range. 

Overall, I felt comfortable during the visit, but the physician was concerned about the abdominal mass and the ongoing mild pain.
options:
A. Polycystic kidney disease B. Lymphoma C. Acute leukemia D. Wilms' tumor E. Neuroblastoma F. Renal cell carcinoma G. Ovarian cyst
"
default:
A smooth, nontender, left-sided abdominal mass that doesn’t cross the midline is most consistent with an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly) or a splenic lesion. Other possibilities (less likely given the exam) include a mass of the left kidney, tail-of-pancreas lesion, or an ovarian/colonic mass depending on sex and exact location — but the exam description strongly favors splenic involvement.

Recommended next steps
- Abdominal ultrasound as the initial imaging test to confirm spleen enlargement and characterize the mass (cystic vs solid) — fast, noninvasive, and widely available.  
- Basic targeted labs: peripheral smear (look for hemolysis or abnormal cells), reticulocyte count, bilirubin/haptoglobin/LDH if hemolysis is suspected, liver tests, and viral serologies (EBV/CMV) if infectious mononucleosis is a consideration. You already have a normal CBC and renal panel, which is helpful but not definitive.  
- Consider CT abdomen with contrast if ultrasound is inconclusive or suggests a solid mass/possible malignancy.  
- Referral to gastroenterology or hematology if splenomegaly is confirmed or if imaging shows a suspicious lesion.

Precautions
- Avoid contact sports or activities with high risk of abdominal trauma until the spleen is evaluated (risk of splenic rupture).  
- Seek urgent care if you develop sudden severe abdominal pain, lightheadedness, fainting, fevers, or signs of bleeding.

If you want, tell me the exact location (upper vs lower left quadrant, moves with inspiration?), your age/sex, and any history of recent infections, bruising, weight loss, or travel — I can refine the differential and testing plan.

question:
I am a 49-year-old man who was brought to the emergency department by ambulance due to sudden-onset chest pain. This pain began while I was having dinner about two hours prior. The discomfort was substernal and radiated into my neck and down my left arm. 

I have a medical history that includes hypercholesterolemia, which I manage with statin therapy, and coronary artery disease. Upon arrival at the hospital, my temperature was recorded at 37.0°C (98.6°F). My blood pressure was noted to be 155/90 mm Hg, my pulse was 112 beats per minute, and my respiratory rate was 25 breaths per minute. 

The medical staff conducted tests, including measuring my troponin I levels, which were elevated. Additionally, they performed a 12-lead ECG to gather more information about my condition. Based on my symptoms and medical history, the healthcare team began assessing the likely cause of my presentation.
options: A. Coronary vasospasm B. Left main coronary artery occlusion C. Left circumflex artery occlusion D. Left anterior descending artery occlusion E. Right main coronary artery occlusion
default:
Most likely diagnosis: acute myocardial infarction (an acute coronary syndrome due to ischemic myocardial injury from coronary atherosclerotic plaque rupture with thrombus). The elevated troponin plus classic ischemic chest pain (substernal pain radiating to neck/left arm) and known coronary disease strongly point to MI. Whether it is a STEMI or NSTEMI depends on the 12‑lead ECG:

- If the ECG shows new ST‑segment elevations in a coronary distribution → STEMI: requires immediate reperfusion (primary PCI ideally within 90 minutes, or fibrinolysis if PCI is not available promptly).  
- If the ECG shows no ST elevation but other ischemic changes (ST depression, T‑wave changes) → NSTEMI: treat with antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy and risk‑stratify for early invasive angiography.

Typical immediate management (what ED/PCI teams will consider)
- Give chewable aspirin immediately (unless contraindicated). Start a P2Y12 inhibitor and anticoagulation as indicated.  
- Give high‑intensity statin (continue existing statin).  
- Give sublingual nitroglycerin for pain if not hypotensive, and consider beta‑blocker if no contraindication.  
- Oxygen only if hypoxic (SpO2 < 90%).  
- Repeat ECGs and serial troponins, obtain bedside echocardiogram if needed, and prepare for urgent cardiology evaluation/angiography.

Follow the treating clinicians’ recommendations—they will use the ECG, serial troponins, hemodynamics, and local PCI capability to choose immediate therapy. If you want, tell me the ECG findings and I can say whether this is most consistent with STEMI or NSTEMI and what the next steps would be.

question:
I am a 51-year-old man who recently found myself in the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain and cramping that had persisted for the past three hours. The pain radiated to my back, and I experienced multiple episodes of vomiting. 

Throughout my life, I have faced challenges with alcohol, which has led to repeated hospitalizations for intoxication and abdominal pain. During this visit, my body temperature was elevated at 103.8°F (39.8°C). My respiratory rate was 15 breaths per minute, my pulse was 107 beats per minute, and my blood pressure measured 100/80 mm Hg. 

The pain was so intense that I refused a physical examination, as I found it difficult to tolerate. I understood that the medical staff would conduct blood work to assess my condition. While I was aware of the various tests they would perform, I did not focus on the specific results at that moment. My primary concern was the overwhelming pain and discomfort I was experiencing. I hoped for relief and clarity on my condition as the medical team continued to evaluate my situation.
options: A. Cholecystitis B. Pancreatitis C. Choledocholithiasis D. Duodenal peptic ulcer E. Gallbladder cancer
default:
Thanks — based on what you described, the most likely diagnosis is acute pancreatitis, most often from alcohol in someone with a long history of heavy drinking. The classic features you gave are: sudden severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, repeated vomiting, fever, tachycardia and borderline blood pressure.

What the ED was likely checking and what they might find
- Serum lipase (most specific) and amylase — pancreatitis is likely if lipase (or amylase) is >3× the upper limit of normal.  
- CBC — may show leukocytosis.  
- Basic metabolic panel — check BUN/creatinine, electrolytes (hypocalcemia can occur), glucose.  
- Hematocrit — hemoconcentration (high Hct) suggests more severe disease/need for aggressive fluids.  
- Liver tests (AST, ALT, bilirubin) and alkaline phosphatase — to look for gallstone cause.  
- CRP — rises with inflammation (peaks later, helps gauge severity).  
- Blood gas if worried about respiratory function or acid/base.  
- Blood cultures only if you suspect infection (fever doesn’t always mean infected pancreas).  
- Imaging: RUQ ultrasound to look for gallstones; contrast CT abdomen usually performed if diagnosis is uncertain or to assess severity/complications (often done 48–72 hours after onset unless clinically necessary earlier).

Why fever doesn’t necessarily mean infection
- High fever and SIRS can occur early from inflammation. Infected pancreatic necrosis is typically a later complication (usually >1 week). Antibiotics are not given routinely unless infection is proven or strongly suspected.

Initial treatment you should expect in the ED/hospital
- Aggressive IV fluids (crystalloids, often lactated Ringer’s) to maintain BP and perfusion.  
- IV pain control (opioids are commonly used).  
- Antiemetics and NPO (no oral intake) initially.  
- Monitor vitals, urine output, and labs closely; transfer to ICU if hypotension, respiratory failure, renal failure or other organ dysfunction.  
- Treat alcohol withdrawal risk: thiamine and appropriate meds (benzodiazepines) if needed.  
- If gallstone pancreatitis is suspected, surgical/gastroenterology consultation for possible ERCP or cholecystectomy may be needed.

How severity is assessed
- Several scores exist (BISAP, Ranson, APACHE II). Important clinical markers of severe disease: persistent hypotension, organ failure (respiratory, renal, cardiovascular), rising hematocrit or BUN, and imaging evidence of necrosis or complications.

When to get urgent help
- Worsening shortness of breath, dropping blood pressure, decreasing urine output, worsening mental status, or continuing severe uncontrolled pain are red flags and require immediate escalation.

If you want, tell me any lab results or imaging they gave you and I can help interpret them and explain next steps.

question:
I am a 62-year-old man who visited the emergency department due to hematuria and hemoptysis that began that morning. Throughout my adult life, I have experienced frequent lung infections, with the most recent one occurring two weeks ago. I have had hematuria on two previous occasions, but the severity I experienced this time was unprecedented. 

In terms of my medical history, it is quite non-significant aside from these issues, and I only take acetaminophen as needed for discomfort. Upon arrival at the emergency department, my blood pressure was recorded at 136/92 mm Hg, my heart rate was 86 beats per minute, my respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute, and my temperature was normal at 37.0°C (98.6°F). 

A chest X-ray revealed a resolving opacity in my right middle lobe, suggesting some recent lung involvement. While I was in the examination room, I unexpectedly developed a spontaneous nosebleed. The medical team conducted initial laboratory tests, which indicated elevated levels of inflammatory markers, but I am not aware of the specific details. Overall, I felt concerned about my symptoms and their implications for my health.
options: A. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis B. IgA nephropathy C. Goodpasture syndrome D. Minimal change disease E. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
default:
Thanks — this picture is worrying for a “pulmonary–renal syndrome” (simultaneous lung bleeding/ inflammation and kidney involvement). The two most likely causes here are:

- ANCA-associated vasculitis (most likely granulomatosis with polyangiitis/GPA given the recurrent lung problems and spontaneous epistaxis)  
- Anti–glomerular basement membrane (anti‑GBM, Goodpasture) disease

Why I suspect this
- Hemoptysis + recurrent hematuria (and prior episodes of blood in the urine) = involvement of lung and kidney.  
- Epistaxis and prior recurrent lung infections fit with upper–airway and pulmonary involvement seen in GPA.  
- Chest x‑ray showing a resolving opacity could reflect an inflammatory nodule/cavitary lesion or prior pulmonary hemorrhage rather than simple infection.

What needs to be done urgently
1. Hospital admission and immediate specialist involvement: nephrology and rheumatology (and ENT/pulmonology if active bleeding).  
2. Important tests now:
   - Urinalysis with microscopy (look for dysmorphic RBCs, RBC casts) and urine protein.  
   - Serum creatinine, BUN, electrolytes, CBC, coagulation studies.  
   - ANCA panel (c‑ANCA/PR3 and p‑ANCA/MPO) and anti‑GBM antibodies.  
   - Chest CT (better defines lung lesions) and consider bronchoscopy if active pulmonary hemorrhage.  
   - Blood and urine cultures if infection is a concern.  
   - If kidney involvement is confirmed or labs deteriorate, a renal biopsy (often diagnostic: crescentic glomerulonephritis).

3. Immediate management considerations
   - Supportive care (airway protection, oxygen, transfuse if needed, stop any anticoagulants).  
   - If a life‑threatening pulmonary hemorrhage or rapidly progressive renal failure is present, treatment is urgent and often started before all results return: high‑dose intravenous corticosteroids plus disease‑specific therapy — plasmapheresis and cyclophosphamide (or rituximab) are commonly used depending on whether anti‑GBM or ANCA disease is responsible. Decisions will be made by nephrology/rheumatology.

What to watch for (seek emergency care)
- Increasing shortness of breath, ongoing or worsening hemoptysis, dizziness or fainting, decreased urine output, swelling, or sudden worsening of labs.

Bottom line: This pattern requires urgent inpatient evaluation for ANCA‑associated vasculitis or anti‑GBM disease. Please get admitted, have the tests above done, and involve nephrology and rheumatology right away. If you’d like, tell me results of any labs/imaging and I can help interpret them.

question:
I am a 10-month-old infant who was brought in by my parents due to concerns about my health. I had been vomiting multiple times over the past couple of hours, and my most recent vomit was green in color. My parents mentioned that I had not passed any stool during this time. 

Upon arrival at the medical facility, I was examined by a healthcare professional. During the examination, I was found to be irritable and crying. The doctor palpated my abdomen and discovered an abdominal mass in the periumbilical region. 

Given these findings, an emergency laparotomy was performed to investigate further. The procedure revealed that a part of my intestine had folded into the section adjacent to it. This condition led to my symptoms and required immediate medical intervention.
options: A. Hirschsprung’s disease B. Meckel’s diverticulum C. Duodenal atresia D. Pyloric stenosis E. Intussusception
default:
Diagnosis: intussusception (most likely ileocolic intussusception).

Explanation: the intestine telescopes (folds) into the adjacent segment, causing bowel obstruction — bilious (green) vomiting, failure to pass stool, irritability/crying, and a palpable abdominal mass are classic. This is a surgical emergency; reduction is done by enema if feasible, or by operative reduction as in this case.

question:
I arrived at the emergency department due to severe pain and swelling in the proximal joint of my right hand's third finger. This pain was so intense that it woke me from sleep earlier that morning. I had never experienced anything like this before. 

For the past 25 years, I have been smoking about a pack of cigarettes daily and consuming alcohol heavily on weekends. Last night, I attended a party where I drank 3 to 4 beers and was unable to drive home afterward. I do not have any significant past medical history, but my family health history includes my mother, who passed away from pancreatic cancer at 55, and my father, who died from a stroke two years ago.

When I was examined, my temperature was noted at 37.7°C, with a blood pressure of 130/70 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 104 beats per minute. I was in moderate distress from the pain. The examination revealed that the proximal interphalangeal joint of my third finger was very tender, swollen, warm, and slightly red. Due to the extreme tenderness, the range of motion could not be assessed. 

A synovial fluid aspiration was performed on the joint, and the findings included cloudy, dense yellow fluid with a high white blood cell count and negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals.
options: A. Pseudogout B. Chronic gout C. Septic arthritis D. Acute gout E. Reactive arthritis
default:
You have an acute gout attack (acute monoarticular gouty arthritis) of the proximal interphalangeal joint. The synovial fluid findings—cloudy yellow fluid with a very high WBC count and negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals—are diagnostic for monosodium urate crystal arthritis (gout). (By contrast, calcium pyrophosphate crystals in pseudogout are rhomboid-shaped and positively birefringent.)

What this means now
- The painful, swollen, red, warm joint and low-grade fever are typical of an acute gout flare.  
- Because septic arthritis can sometimes coexist, synovial fluid should also be sent for Gram stain and culture (and empiric antibiotics started only if infection is suspected or confirmed).

Immediate treatment options (choose based on your other medical problems)
- First-line: NSAIDs if no contraindication (e.g., indomethacin 50 mg TID or naproxen 500 mg BID) until the attack settles (usually several days).
